rev_det.name:
I am 58 years old, overweight, and have just been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes. Talk about a wake-up call. I have been advised to walk 30 minutes per day at least 4 times per week. My husband is going through health problems (CLL / leukemia, and extreme Iron deficiency, which leaves me unable to leave home to do my walking. I researched many Treadmills before deciding to purchase this one. Here are the reasons I chose this machine. #1-price was reasonable, #2-machine takes up less room than most other Treadmills, #3-machine is wider than all others I looked at, #4-handlebars are longer, with start / stop on buttons left side bar and increase / decrease buttons on right side bar, which makes it very easy to get to whenever you need to make adjustments, or stop. (I read where some people did not like this feature because it was where you naturally place your hands, so they accidentally turn machine off. This is partly true, but that is 1 of the reasons I chose this machine. The Heart rate monitor is directly below these buttons, so that is where you keep your hands.) If you are or plan to be a power walker or runner, this machine is not for you, it only goes up to 4 miles per hour. However, I will never power walk or run, so 4 miles per hour is faster than I will ever need. Why pay extra money for more machine than you need. #5-Display is easy to read, #6-info said this machine is quiet. That is an understatement. I talk with my husband while walking, without raising my voice, I watch T.V. without needing to turn volume up at all. It is unbelievably quiet, and #7-I really like the safety clip. This one has one end that clips to your clothes like a clothespin, the other end that attaches to the machine is a magnet, making it easy to pull away from machine quickly, in case of an accidental fall, very good safety feature.
Box is very heavy. You will need 2 people to get box moved and in place. Once machine is out of box, it is a 1 person job to mount control panel and move to desired location. Wheels are very small, and you may be like us, at first we thought they we not in box. They are attached to frame, so even though they are small, they work well. The box was delivered with damage, however, machine was in perfect condition, due to proper protection inside of box. I have told everyone I know, buy this Treadmill. Now I am telling you. Happy Walking.
P.S. I forgot to tell you, I have walked 30 minutes per day, every single day, since I have had this Treadmill. I love it!

I am a 300+ pound middle-aged man with back and leg problems due to a number of blown discs over the years. I have a fair amount of trouble walking, so I wanted to try to increase my coordination and stamina with a treadmill. I was a little skeptical about this product given the price but decided it was worth the risk, given the price of the average "name brand" unit. I'm glad I did.
This thing is rather amazingly solid for something of its size/price. The design is quite clever in its use of leverage to buoy up the overall sturdiness and rigidity; the "C" shape of the floor supports, uprights and grab bars, coupled with the low center of gravity, means that the thing moves around very little during use. It's also pretty quiet: the frame creaked and groaned a little when I first started using it but adjusting the floor shims and skooctching the thing around on the floor a little allowed it to settle in. The grab bars are nice and long, a real necessity in my case. The only other treadmills I found on Amazon with bars of equal or greater length cost a great deal more. Like every treadmill made since the beginning of time, the control panel sits way too far forward of the "upstream" end of the belt....apparently these things are primarily designed for use by people with the arm-length-to-body-height ratio of an orangutan. The little cubbies on either side of the control face are great for storing spare change or perhaps a cigarette lighter, but are useless for anything larger. No big deal, I used Velcro to slap my tablet, stereo remote and other gadgets all over the thing, and you can always zip-tie a holster for a water bottle to the frame somewhere. I'm seriously thinking of disabling the grab-bar-mounted controls, as they are placed where I tend to want to put my hands, but that's going to be different for everyone. Fortunately the controls are joined to the control panel by a wire harness, so I ought to be able to pull the plug on them if I decide I want to.
Amazing, huh? Yes. This is a great product. However, I am deducting two stars for the company's hilariously underwhelming customer service.
In the process of jiggering with the belt tensioners (a tip for new users: if you need to retension the belt, put the belt in its vertical "stored" position first. That way the retensioners are right at eye level, and you can easily look at the whole of the belt while making the adjustments), I overstressed and cracked one of the caps that cover the back ends of the foot rails. They are purely decorative, but I thought I would order a replacement, and while I was at it, ask the customer service representative about the retensioning processâhow tight is too tight, etc. I called the toll-free number (nice touch), and was greeted by the worst, I mean the w o r s t voice-chip phone greeting I have ever heard in my life. If you are a fan of South Park, think of the voice of the "Shake Weight" in that episode. Its cadence and pronunciation were actually a little nauseating to listen to. I'm imagining that the owner of the company bought a turn-key hardware/software telephony package and decided to use the default voice-synth option rather than recording an outgoing message him/herself....bad move. The voice warbled at me that all CSRs were busy and that if I left my name and number someone would get back to me, so I did. Now a week later, and I have yet to hear from anyone....and I even mentioned in my message that I wanted to buy replacement partsâthat is to say, that I wanted to spend more money with them.
This is the dark flip-side of this amazing Information Age in which we live. The ability to asses a company before you buy their wares has diminished considerably. It is entirely possible for a single person to masquerade as a complete business, with all of the attendant infrastructure. Even an impressive Web site is just a matter of a few dollars and several hours' worth of dragging and dropping. I get the feeling that "Paradigm Health & Wellness" is one person sitting in an attached-garage office in a residential neighborhood, with maybe a decommissioned 20-foot shipping container for a "warehouse." I could very well be wrong, but nothing in my experience to date has suggested otherwise.
Would I recommend buying one of these treadmills? Yes, I would; I'm very impressed with mine. But keep the packaging for the first two weeks, and maybe take pictures of the unit as packaged before assembling it so you'll know how to get it back in the box. If you have any issues, you're going to want to avail yourself of Amazon's generous return policy, because I'm not sure you will have any other options.

This treadmill only gets 1-star because of the complete and total lack of customer support from the manufacturer.
The treadmill arrived in a very big and heavy box. The box had some minor scrapes and gouges, but it was heavy-duty cardboard with reinforcements in the corners. There was no damage to the contents.
I was able to unpack and assemble the treadmill with no assistance, but it was a challenge to get it out of the box, especially in the small, crowded living room in which it was going (I'm a 63-year old slightly overweight senior male). The assembly instructions were pretty much worthless, but what little assembly was needed was pretty obvious.
The treadmill seems very well made and sturdy. My wife has been using it for an hour a day for two weeks now without any problems. The motor and belt are very quiet, and it is easy to listen to the TV without having to crank up the volume. The treadmill is short and relatively compact -- a feature we needed -- but neither my wife nor I have any trouble with staying in the main tread area and any of its speeds. The belt is wide and there is plenty of room between the hand rails for arms to swing (and neither of us are skinny). The long side arms do not get in the way, and are essential for my wife who occasionally has some balance problems. The control buttons on the side arms are convenient, and we quickly learned where to position our hands so as to not inadvertently hit them.
The two pockets in the console are worthless. The would be deep enough to hold things like a TV remote or water bottle, but are at such a steep angle that anything put in them vibrates out within seconds when the treadmill is being used. Fortunately, I have a pedal desk (also made by Paradigm Health and Wellness) sitting right next to the treadmill, that has very useful holders for a TV remote and bottle of water.
The treadmill is plastered with very large, obnoxious legal warning stickers that are a ghastly red, orange or yellow. It is impossible to remove the stickers without damaging the paint or plastic parts. It would seem that the manufacturer, Paradigm Health and Wellness, is owned and operated by paranoid lawyers who are certain that anyone who even looks at the treadmill is going to sue them. This treadmill sits in our living room, and these unsightly legal warning stickers are a major eyesore.
The reason for the 1-star review is because my wife called Paradigm's customer support number with a simple question. There is a funny looking symbol on the display with a "T" inside a circle and a number next to it that varies between 19 and 21 during her workout. The mode button and other controls have no effect on this part of the display. The very short owner's manual does not talk about the display at all, and we cannot figure out what "T 19" could possible mean. My wife has tried calling the customer support number in the owner's multiple times and only gets an answering machine telling her to leave a message and a support person will call back. We have not received a call back after two weeks.
I cannot recommend buying a product, no matter how good it is, if the company that makes it does not provide customer support.
UPDATE 3/30/17: We have now had this treadmill for a month. My wife uses it 3 to 4 days a week for 45 minutes each time. After 3 weeks, the treadmill started going berserk. While in use, it would suddenly speed up to its max speed. Holding down the minus button for the speed would slow the treadmill down, but as soon as the button was released it would speed back up again. This would happen several times before the treadmill would final stay at the slower speed. Turning the treadmill off and on, would not help. As soon as it was turned on again, it would race up to its maximum speed. THIS IS A MAJOR SAFETY HAZARD! My wife has leg problems, and cannot walk at the max speed of the treadmill. When it would suddenly speed up, she was be thrown off the back of treadmill more than once if she was not able to step onto the side platforms quickly enough.
I found that the problem is a design and manufacturing defect. The foam tube on the left side hand rail can slide on the steel pipe. The foam had slid down into the speed control switch on the handrail, and caused the UP speed button to stick. I had to loosen the set screw underneath the speed switch, and slide the foam back to its original position (it had only slipped about 1/2 inch). The UP speed button would then function correctly. I have fixed it temporarily by putting a zip-tie around the tube at its furthest forward spot. That has prevented the tube from slipping so far, but the zip-tie end is in the way when holding the railing where it is located.
Other reviewers have reported this same type of failure with this treadmill. The failure should be well-known to the manufacturer, Paradigm Health & Wellness, but they do not seem to be inclined to fix this problem. Paradigm Health & Wellness needs to send customers a proper fix for this problem with the foam tubing slipping before they get SUED!
Paradigm Health customer support has still not responded to my initial call for support, noted in my original review. After 30 days, however, Paradigm Health did send an automated e-mail saying they were closing the support call as being resolved. This company still deserves less than a 1-star review because of their total lack of support and concern for their customers.

About a year ago, I decided to try and change my lifestyle and lose weight. Weighing 341 pounds and on the wrong side of 40, part of my plan included adding exercise to my daily routine. So I bought a treadmill. This treadmill, specifically due to it's competitive price point and it's generous 400-pound weight limit.
One year later, I feel compelled to submit one of the only reviews I've ever submitted for a product on Amazon. I've lost 102 pounds in the last year and this treadmill has been with me on this journey every step of the way. I've beaten the hell out of it, if I'm honest. I think you can imagine the force a 300+ pound man is going to apply on a piece of exercise equipment he's using daily. And the treadmill is clearly showing some wear and tear for sure. The motor is a fair bit louder now than it was back then, the belt squeaks sometimes when you start it up, and occasionally the treadmill will shut down every once in awhile with an "E09" error code that isn't explained in the manual.
But noises and the random error code aside, I can't complain. The frame is still as solid as the day I got it - not even a hint of shake. The motor is still running as good as it ever did. Other than some slight wear along the edges, the belt is in amazingly good shape. I can't speak to the customer service, as I haven't used it. All I can tell you is that this thing is as durable as anything I've ever owned.

Given our experience with this product, I thought I would share it with others.
UPS delivery to your door. Recognize that the box is 60â long, 36â wide and 13â high. It is big. The treadmill itself weighs 120 lbs, add the box and packing material and you are looking at 130 lbs you have to move. You will need two strong people to move the box. If you must go up a stairway (heaven help you), maybe three people. I can see no physical way one person can move this box, put the unit together and then move the unit by themselves. You will need help, someone with muscles and mechanical skills for assembly.
Our box arrived damaged, like someone used a box cutter and cut across the middle of the box. The only obvious damaged was one of the plastic âHandlebar Knobsâ with half the knob you turn broken off. Still usable.
One of the first things you need to decide is whether you will move the unopened box into the room where the treadmill will be located, or assemble the treadmill in say a garage, and then carry the folded treadmill (2 people) to the room. My wife and I messed up and took the box cover off and decided to move the open box to the room. So we needed to use rope around the opened box to hold the unit in the box, raised the box up on its long side, and using towels to protect the floor and ease of sliding, pushed and slid the box into the room where the treadmill was going to be located, about 50 feet from the garage on the same floor. Knowing what I know now, I would have assembled the unit in the garage and then we would have folded the unit as it can be folded, and then carried the folded unit to the room. Live and learn!
Assembly: I would strongly recommend that the ProGear/Paradigm Health and Wellness people bring in customers who are unfamiliar with the unit and watch them follow the âassembly instructionsâ and the problems they encounter. The instructions were obviously written by someone who knows the unit, knows how it goes together. The company needs to bring in people totally unfamiliar with the unit, like two 70 year olds, show them the sealed box and watch what they do and the problems they have, never helping them, then rewrite the assembly instructions and add a few extra diagrams. Step 1 of the instructions is totally worthless. My wife and I, college educated, sat looking at the unit once it was out of the box and could not figure out how to execute the first part of Step 1, âPlace the treadmill in the upright positionâ as it does not show effectively how to expand the unit coming right out of the box. It took us almost an hour of looking and experimenting before we thought we knew what to do. And then a problem occurred with one of the spring-loaded knobs that was jammed in its hole, possibly another result of the damaged box. Step 1 is woefully inadequate to instruct a customer on how to expand the machine out of the box. We believe we have the unit assembled as required, but are not sure given the poor Step 1 instructions.
Steps 2-4 were easy to follow, but the diagram in Step 3 is confusing. It shows that the console and the wires going into the base unit need to be connected. However, our consoleâs wires were already connected. One real challenge, the console sits loose in the box, connected to the base unit only by wires. As you are taking the unit out of the box and expanding it per Step 1, the console is dangling free and we were concerned the connections for the wires, not real robust, would break free. We taped the console to the back handlebar to avoid this, and then removed the tape when we started bolting the console to the console bracket.
Operation and Quality: Once assembled, the unit presents a very strong and sturdy piece of exercise equipment comparable to units 2 or 3 times its cost. The unit began operating as expected, and my wife used it this morning for a full 30-minute walk and had no problems. It is very quiet. You could easily watch TV and walk without having the TV sound turned way up. We did notice that the safety tether is a little short if she walks in the middle of the treadmill. It could have another 6 inches to avoid being disconnected by accident. As a future enhancement, we would ask the manufacturer to add a stop switch on the right handlebar by the speed control. Reaching forward to hit the stop button on the console for people with short arms is a challenge.
If I ignore the assembly challenges, the quality and performance after 1 day are quite good for a $400+ walking treadmill. I would give this unit a rating of 5 stars, but I would give the very poor assembly instructions 1 star. But quality and performance outweigh the temporary assembly issues, the reason for the 4 star rating. Just remember, this is a two person job, moving the box, assembling the unit, and then moving the assembled unit to its final position.

I have never used a treadmill before and didnât think I would. When I would see one at a friends home, it dominated the entire room. But when my husband came home from the hospital he needed to getting moving again so I started to search for a dreaded treadmill. I have been pleasantly surprised by this machine. It is sturdy yet not dominating. It was easy for me a 67 year old lady to assemble (not to easy to move as the box was large and heavy). The suggestion to use the packing materials to help set it up was genius. My husband is using the machine several times a day because I have it behind the sofa. It is shorter than the sofa so we can walk around it easily. I would recommend this model for anyone who needs to get up off the chair and get moving. Itâs safe and reliable.

The worse instruction's manuel for assembly I've ever come across. I think it was written by a 5th grader. I take that back, don't want to insult 5th graders, they could probably do a better job. The drawing illustrations are horrible and very difficult to understand, instructions are confusing and difficult to follow. There are two pieces needed for folding the thread mill, a safety tube and the air piston, and they're not even mentioned in the instructions and how to install them. Had to use common sense to figure it out. The thread mill comes practically unassembled with the exception of the handrails, everything else you have to put together, and with the horrible badly written instructions manuel it was difficult to put together. Good thing I have plenty of experience putting things together which helped me get through it. It's very heavy, and not easy to move around, even when folded for storage, it's still bulky and doesn't maneuver easily. If you're not experienced in putting things together, I wouldn't recommend you attempt this assembly on your own. You need strength, energy, common sense, and patients. The upside, once put together and running, it does operate smooth and very quite, the computer is easy to operate, and the controls button on the handrails to control speed, on/off switch and speed are a nice feature. And by holding the handrails with both hands over the pulse censor, keeps track of your heart rate. It was too bad, I had to have a bad experience with the horrible instructions manuel, and difficulty of putting it together before I could enjoy it.

EDIT 2: I sent an email as directed by the company. I was supposed to get a reply in 3-4 days. After a week I paid to have this piece of junk hauled off because I don't have room to have something this large wasting space in my home. After OVER a week, they contact me, tell me if I ship it back they can refund me (most people aren't going to keep defective and useless products sitting indefinitely). I informed them I just had it shipped of to the dump, was told "oh, nevermind, we assumed you'd keep up junk trashing up your home for a while, bye". Yeah, so their customer support is as horrible as their products. Spend your money elsewhere.
EDIT: Just to include a pic of the broken roller. Treadmill supposed to be rated for 400 lbs, yet 220 lbs caused that breakage so you can figure out yourself based on the weight you're at how much you'd trust it.
With light use, regular maintenance, died about 2 1/2 years in. Which is insanely low for a treadmill (our last one lasted 9 years). Would NOT recommend the brand.
I've been on treadmills that were not motor driven that were more sturdily built. This one didn't even have the guide on it to keep the belt on track (probably what led to the insanely short time before it met an end), so you'd have to constantly adjust the belt one way or the other, even when you got it perfect, next time you use it it would go back off center again and need adjusted. Pathetic.

After about one year I've started having problems with a clacking noise from the back area of the treadmill. I thought maybe loosening the belt could help, but no way. It seems to get louder the faster this treadmill runs. I've gone to the website of my ProGear HCXL 4000 Treadmill where they have "Live Assist". After waiting 15 minutes it appeared no one was mining that area. Also, there does not seem to be a working forum where I can contact other users to see if any are having the same situation and what they do to eradicate the problem. The knocking noise sound serious to me. I'm just hoping the treadmill is not ready to be trashed. I am convinced there is no customer service assist. I have not been able to contact anyone from the company regarding my problem with this treadmill. Has anyone else had a problem with this product and was able to contact customer service? Before I purchased this product, I checked out many of the reviews here and then decided to buy. I am convinced buying a product such as this may not be the best choice. The only way to have repairs done is have someone come to our home since this item is too heavy to load in the SUV. We may have to end up calling our local Salvation Army to come pick this up as a donation. It only held up for one year and that's not good at all.

We have had our treadmill for a little under Six months now and it already doesn't work. I've tried Calling and emailing customer service but they stil haven't responded and it's been 3 days. Make sure you hang on to your owners manual and reveipt. I love the treadmill and this is really disheartening to me. The problem is it won't go off the safe mode. I'll keep this updated as I figure this out.

Very heavy. 2 people of sufficient strength required to unpack and assemble. The instructions are incomplete. The hydraulic arm on the right side and the locking bracket on the left side of the treadmill were not attached. No instruction for them. No clear photos of how they are attached. We turned the apparatus on its side to assemble the hydraulic arm and locking bracket. The stabilizer bar at the front of the bottom frame was difficult to attach. The remainder of the assembly went according to directions. The adjuster pads that go on the bottom of the stabilizer need to be installed before use; turn on side. Total assembly time was about 2 hours. Missing bolts for the bracket for the computer control panel. When finally assembled, the arm rests and vertical frame are somewhat loose, and no further adjustment.

Came a day earlier than expected which is normally a great thing. In this case it was not. I had arranged for a friend to be available to help move this gigantic 150 lb box into the house, instead I struggled to do it myself. It was a bit rough to put together. A suggestion would be to attach the computer part to the top rail at the earliest possible time to prevent it from dangling and being bounced around possibly loosening connections. The tread was moving to one side and as I attempted to make adjustments was just not sure the directions were correct. Beware, this machine may fold up and be portable but don't think that if you have company coming you can move it from the livingroom to the bedroom out of the way. It is too wide to roll through a doorway unless perhaps a handicap doorframe is wide enough. Still, I am happy with the product and it seems very sturdy for a large person. Now to master the art of walking without using the handrails......

Unit arrived and was assembled without incident. When powered on for the first time, the treadmill display seemed to be working properly. Unfortunately, when I actually tried to start the treadmill belt, it moves about 2 feet and then the display shows "Er5". I followed the manual's troubleshooting instructions for this error with no success.
The manual indicated that the likely cause of the "Er5" error was either a bad motor or a bad Power IC Board. I attempted to contact ParadigmHW.Com (parent company for ProGear) for support via their website AND via email, then waited for two weeks (they promise a 1-2 day response time) and got NO response other than an automated email that my message had been received.
In a last-ditch attempt to repair the unit, I submitted a third support request asking specifically for the Power IC Board (I'm just guessing this is the problem, since the motor appears undamaged) to be replaced under warranty. After three days (the site promises a 1-2 day response time) I have still not received any response other than the "we received your request" automated response.
Not only did the unit arrive non-functional, but the technical support is literally non-existent. I will likely NOT be purchasing any Paradigm Health & Wellness products going forward since they have no support after the sale.

It was awkward getting 149# up the stairs with help; but did it rather quickly. Setup was easy except I could not pull out the pin that lowers the bars. Phoned Customer Service on Friday, then read reviews about their service. This is the time for holiday business; so, I figured I would wait until Monday to phone again. Tried to pull out the pin again after lowering the back bar, and it pulled out. Got the call from Customer Service Sunday night. Informed I fixed the problem. He was courteous and patient. Said he just got my message after being quite busy. Asked if there was anything else he could do; if not, to phone anytime and he will get back to me. Treadmill is perfect my needs and my dog. Nice and short in length, too. This is the season to have patience because we all want things now, and there are others ahead of us. HAPPY HOLIDAYS!

This treadmill is great!! It took a loooong time for me to assemble but it was well worth the trouble.
Pros:
It's freakishly quiet! I warned my downstairs neighbor ahead of time that I was getting a treadmill but he never, ever hears it! If you are like me, shopping for a reasonably priced treadmill that will hold a very large person, this is it. You can stop shopping. Its wide, built for us and sturdy as all get out.
Cons:
There is no point of folding it up since it takes up a significant amount of space either way. I just leave it down. The display is meh. The controls near the bp sensors on the handles are kind of a pain. I always accidently hit them.

Works very well for persons of portly stature; being sturdy and well constructed. It is not at all flimsy. User can choose to walk very slowly or any speed they desire and can hold on to side rails or walk free if desired. Very happy with this treadmill. Easy to adjust speed control and good safety switch to shut unit off if user stumbles or starts to fall.
Although setup is supposed to be easy if unit arrives undamaged, my unit arrived with both bottom support tubes bent out of round as if the unit had been dropped during shipment. So rather than go through the hassle of returns or claims, I found that I could readily bend the tubes back into round using a 36" crowbar. The tubes must be round before the bottom support legs can be inserted. No other hidden damage and rest of setup was easy, taking about 20 minutes.
Be aware that you will need help carrying the unit into your home because of its weight. However once it is setup it can be moved by one person.

This is a great little treadmill if you're looking for a very basic treadmill walking. I have no fault with the treadmill and would rate it five stars but read your warranty. They only warranty the parts. When we set it up there was a clunking noise every time we tried to walk on it. I contacted the vendor and sent a audio recording of the noise and they said it probably was a bearing in either the front or back roller. They would happily send me new rollers. When I inquired if they had people in the area that installed them they said no that's up to you. Brand-new machine with a problem with the bearings in one of the rollers and their solutions were one to send me the rollers and have me figure out how to put them in. They do have a video on how to get them out that they will send you a link to. Their other option was I could return the treadmill to Amazon because I was with in my 90 days. To do that I would have to take the treadmill part find some way to wrap it up since I had recycled the box it came in already and then get it someplace to ship it. Hopefully I wouldn't have to pay for the shipping. When the rollers came they did not have any directions for installing them. So it's great when it works but if you have a problem you're on your own to fix it unless you're under warranty and then they will supply only the parts.

I'm at 360 pounds and coming down slowly. This treadmill is great for me winter is comming. My income doesn't allow me to buy one of the over $1,000. models. I use a walker so the stationary handles were a must. Just enough whistles and bells to keep me happy for years to come.

Purchased August 2020. Used average 3 x per week since. Last week started vibrating and making very loud noise. I have tried multiple times to get a real person to contact me from Paradigm. They are not taking phone calls. I tried emailing several times. It is clear they have some type of automated response set up asking you to submit proof of purchase, serial# etc. which I have provided. Tried chat on their website. Again a robot auto response that a rep will be with me shortly, then right after that, no reps are available and to leave a message. You cannot leave a message on Chat! There are several similar complaints with the Better Business Bureau. Amazon should discontinue selling any equipment with this company's involvement. I have an almost new treadmill still under warranty that I cannot use and I cannot get any help!!!
Built really well however I wish the arms we longer and could adjust the positions or height of arms. Really heavy duty and stable. Would recommend to anyone wanting a walking thredmill.

The on/off switch is right on the bar where you put your hand. I finally had to rig something to cover it, because I was sick of turning off my treadmill right in the middle of using it. Other than that, it's OK. There is nowhere to put an iPad or a phone so you will have to figure something else out. It's just an odd set up all together. Even the cup holders are slanted so you can't properly put a drink in them.

This product works even if your over the limit however you want to speed up slowly as it doesnât always gradually increase. If you increase you may find yourself almost jogging before it adjusts to the speed you need. As long as you adjust speed up slowly it works just fine for a larger person walking and trying to get in shape. Not sure if I would trust it running because of how it increases but overall Iâm happy with it because itâs something that can hold me without costing 2 grand

*Update*
Treadmill just broke down after owning it barely a year with little to no use. I'm very dissatisfied and will be seeking a refund or replacement.
*Previous Review*
Not a bad treadmill for obese people. Assembly took me longer than it should have. I feel like most of the parts could have come preinstalled. Motor seems a little weak, but the frame is very strong and sturdy. Belt seems to stutter alot. Don't think this will last, but it's holding up so far.

I like to size of the walking tread, the handlebars with controls, and the quietness. I have tried to contact customer ervice both by phone and e-mail regarding the pulse register not working. Customer Service for Paradigm Health & Wellness does not answer phone and sends a non-answer automated e-mail back with no response to my question.

For its price point it works well for workouts the bars are nicely designed wide apart and comfortable height. the cons are my partner and I had a hard time putting it together. it was a little beat up the wheels looked used and it has little dings and cuts on it. I will also say the dashboard sometimes random turns on ? So we unplug when itâs not in use. itâs not easy to move so set it up where you want it to live. One major flaw in the design is that an off button is right next to the pulse check so itâs easy to accidentally turn it off. The shipping box was completely beat up and way to thin for the size of this thing. But all that said for the weight range and price itâs okay.

I have had this treadmill for about 5 weeks now and I really enjoy it. I use it everyday and walk several miles on it. I have had no issues and it was easy to setup. I would recommend it to almost anyone unless you have really long legs and you might have an issue with the deck length.

Overall very pleased with item. Easily set up. Wide enough and sturdy. The one thing I will say it is clearly marked on the box âwalkingâ treadmill and in the handbook that came with it clearly states DO NOT jog or run. I was only planning to walk on it, especially since I live in an apartment and donât want to be noisy, so Iâm still very pleased with it. Perhaps if you are way below the weight limit it would be ok to jog on it as advertised?
LOVE THIS TREADMILL!! I can watch TV while using it! It's so quite you won't even know it running. A must have!!

I wanted a basic treadmill for walking in my basement gym. Given my height, I needed something with a low deck. After having used it for several weeks, I have zero complaints. It is well constructed and could not have been simpler to setup. It is, however, pretty heavy (which I think is a good thing!) so you might need someone to help with moving it while it is in the box. Given itâs width, I agree with another reviewer who suggested getting it in the room where you intend to use it before unpacking it, otherwise it might be difficult to get through the doorway.
If you want a great treadmill for walking (up to 4 mph) that is reasonably priced and doesnât have all of the âbells and whistlesâ that I didnât need, this should work well for you. I agree with other reviewers that the heart rate monitor is too close to the speed control, but I use my smartphone and chest strap heart rate monitor, so l am not bothered by this issue.

This is my first treadmill ever and for a basic walking treadmill it is very decent and works well. I have had the product for about a week and it is working great. It is difficult to get out of the box since the product is quite heavy and bulky. Would not be bad with two people but I had to do it alone. Once out of the box, it is easy to put together. The treadmill works really well for anyone that is looking for a basic walking only treadmill. The only annoyances I have found it that there is not a pause button and the buttons on the handle bar can get in the way but these are only small grievances.

It fits where I needed it but the track is a bit too short (I'm only 5'5"). If it were just one inch longer it would be better. The placement of the handle switches is awkward. It seems to be the perfect place for my hands and yet, I have to place them above or below (which is probably why my feet slightly get to the back edge). It's a little frustrating, but it serves the purpose. I wouldn't but it again though.

The treadmill worked fine for about 7-9 months in ,then it would start to slow down or speed up on its own I figure it was maybe because my husband & our 3 girls used it everyday this happened for a week then it stop the company sent out power source box for replacement once we finally got in contact with someone,we installed part it worked for about 3 weeks and stopped you could hear motor running but nothing once contacted them again they sent a box out because they wanted their unit 1st before they could send out new refurbished one this took about a month.We got the unit it worked perfect until about the 9-11 months month,(FYI...purchased Around April of 2016,so now we're over in 2016 with different unit same brand & company )...same thing starts to happen the unit would began to speed up on its on we'd give it a break for couple days began to use it again fine for about a week then it'll start speedy up on it's on only way of stopping was disconnected from ac outlet couple weeks it stopped working all together contact company very hard to get an actual person stated we wanted refund to purchase a new unit because we were just over this hassle our daughter needed,needs treadmill to assist with her rehabilitation from cord surgery in her legs,they 1st wanted pictures of unit emailed to them ok done,then we waited on box to return treadmill so called and email they say now they need original owners manual great since I throw away nothing I have it so I send emails of the manual and it has writing where I had spoken to someone earlier and their work I'd # times and dates I called so they finally send a box for fed ex to put up unit around 1st week in December,well tracked with fed ex they have the unit still waiting on our refund it's 2017....keep your money
I do not recommend this product. It stopped working after 3 months. It was such a hassle returning it.

Assembly was easy for my two friends who came by to help set it up. Moving it to where it would actually stay was no problem. However, the belt seems to be rubbing against something... it moves very slowly when I walk on it, almost like itâs a MANUAL treadmill instead of electric. While I am a rather large gal, Iâm FAR from the 400lb capacity limit. Any thoughts? If I get this issue resolved, Iâll most likely change my review to 5 stars across the board.
This is a great basic treadmill for walking. We received one with a damaged lcd screen and the manufacturer sent us a replacement.
The treadmill worked for 3 months and now the display keeps erroring out and the treadmill stops working. Brand new product, should not break after 3 months.

Works for me. Not as well made as some but the price it's great. The belt is shorter than most but I am 5'4" and want to walk slow. Don't know how it work if you want to run. I assembled it by myself, a 70 year woman.

This is perfect for us, my wife is recovering from a heart attack and this duplicates the unit she is using at rehab. Very sturdy, well constructed and works just as advertised. Not for someone looking for a hard aggressive work out but for seniors or someone who has limited mobility this is the perfect machine. Recommend it very highly, miner assembly was a snap.

Hate to report this, but bought this for my father for his birthday. Delivered, unboxed, hour to set up, flipped the switch... nothing. I wrestled with it for an hour, checking every possible reason why down to the fuse and power cord. Never worked. :(
The insult to injury is having to take it all apart again, rebox it as best I could, and lug the 120 pound box to UPS store to return it to Amazon.
Lesson learned. Don't buy something this big and electronic on Amazon.
Got a great one at Walmart instead.

Our ProGear HCXL 4000 Ultimate High Capacity Treadmill arrived Thursday just as promised. I will start by saying 'this thing is HEAVY'. I'm a pretty strong 62 year old woman, but I could not budge this thing. I enlisted the assistance of a strong, young engineer friend from work and he easily moved it into our home using a dolly. Together, we un-boxed it and set it up...he did all the work, but I assisted. :)
This is not my first treadmill, but I chose this one because of it's unique features.
1. The belt is wider than most treadmills made for home use. I love this feature for my husband who's a big guy and has extreme balance issues due to Parkinson's.
2. The handlebars are extra long and have the 'speed' and 'mode' control buttons right on them for easy access.
3. This treadmill is shorter in length than most treadmills made for home use. It doesn't take up so much space.
4. It's super quiet! I love this feature because I like to watch TV while I walk.
5. It was easy to get on and off for hubby who uses a walker.
It's Saturday morning and I just had my first 20 minute walk and the treadmill worked perfectly! I love it already and hope to get years of use from it. By the way, the packaging was excellent and the box arrived without rips, tears, holes, or any other calamities that were mentioned in other reviews. No issues at all. It was easy to unpack and without blemish. (Ladies, you definitely need help though. Don't try this alone.)
That's my review! If my opinion changes over time, I'll let you know.
Very large. Very heavy. Does not roll easily. Does work for higher weight, but is not a high end machine.
It is perfect for beginners. Wise it had a place to put a phone or device to watch or listen to music.

So far so good. I am very please with my purchase. The machine is stable and durable. The motor runs quiet enough I can watch movies and listen music without them being loud. The machine was easy to put together. The hardest part was getting it out of the box. If anything changes I will keep you abreast. Thanks.

I wish it had more cushioning.And I should have paid attention to the highest speed setting.Luckily I have a friend who wants a treadmill for walking,so I will be selling her this one.I need one with higher speeds(for running),and more cushioning.Set at 4, I can speed walk or slow jog.
perfect for my workouts, quiet, easy to use, well built, perfect
GREAT TREADMILL!!!! The box came beaten up. I was scared it wasn't not going to work. Putting it together was SO EASY!!!

Really good product-
Sturdy and can take the 440 pounds - 6.2ft tall me
Setting it up though was a pain ! And progear assistance / customer service is nonexistent
It was easy to put together, made very well, works great
Easy maneuverability and for working out

It wasn't as easy to assemble as was lead to believe. But that said I am happy with the purchase. It runs smoothly even at the slowest speeds. The wide belt and extended handles providing increased security.

This treadmill worked fantastic initially. It ran well, was quiet, and the perfect size for my bedroom. However, after 10 months of moderate use (2-3 hours a week) it developed a problem with the motor and belts. When I called customer service I was told there was only a 90-day warranty on parts. 90-days? Not even a year?
Mathematically that means I paid approximately $3 for each hour that the treadmill worked. No thanks! Go with a different company and a different product :(

The best treadmill for the price. I shopped around for hours and came across this treadmill and decided to give it a try. Set up was easy and this thing runs better than any thousand dollar brand. I highly recommend it..You won't be disappointed.
Came on time, and set up was easy. Love it because it's not so overwhelming big. Just right.

She is not a runner, but being 5' 2" she could probably do a light jog at 4mph if she wanted too. That would be a very brisk walk for me being over 6'. Picking the unit up from Walmart was easy, and the employees helped me load it in my truck. The box is big, almost 6ft long because of the packaging, so you will need a decent vehicle to pick this up with. I use a pickup truck, but maybe an SUV with the seats down might work well too? Getting it inside and set up is definitely a two person job, only due to the weight of the unit. I personally brought it up three flights and set it up inside our condo by myself, but I'm a beast who hits the gym regularly, and no one was around to help me today. Setup was easy, and I place it on a treadmill mat. This extends the life of the unit by protecting the motor from dust, and hopefully saves the carpet too. I did have to adjust the alignment of the belt just a hair, was to the right a bit, but was really simple following the instructions in the enclosed manual. I feel this was a decent purchase for the price in comparison to high-end units that I've seen being sold for thousands. I hope it holds up well, and if it does not, I'll be back to update my review.

I am 58 years old, overweight, and have just been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes. Talk about a wake-up call. I have been advised to walk 30 minutes per day at least 4 times per week. My husband is going through health problems (CLL / leukemia, and extreme Iron deficiency, which leaves me unable to leave home to do my walking. I researched many Treadmills before deciding to purchase this one. Here are the reasons I chose this machine. #1-price was reasonable, #2-machine takes up less room than most other Treadmills, #3-machine is wider than all others I looked at, #4-handlebars are longer, with start / stop on buttons left side bar and increase / decrease buttons on right side bar, which makes it very easy to get to whenever you need to make adjustments, or stop. (I read where some people did not like this feature because it was where you naturally place your hands, so they accidentally turn machine off. This is partly true, but that is 1 of the reasons I chose this machine. The Heart rate monitor is directly below these buttons, so that is where you keep your hands.) If you are or plan to be a power walker or runner, this machine is not for you, it only goes up to 4 miles per hour. However, I will never power walk or run, so 4 miles per hour is faster than I will ever need. Why pay extra money for more machine than you need. #5-Display is easy to read, #6-info said this machine is quiet. That is an understatement. I talk with my husband while walking, without raising my voice, I watch T.V. without needing to turn volume up at all. It is unbelievably quiet, and #7-I really like the safety clip. This one has one end that clips to your clothes like a clothespin, the other end that attaches to the machine is a magnet, making it easy to pull away from machine quickly, in case of an accidental fall, very good safety feature.
Box is very heavy. You will need 2 people to get box moved and in place. Once machine is out of box, it is a 1 person job to mount control panel and move to desired location. Wheels are very small, and you may be like us, at first we thought they we not in box. They are attached to frame, so even though they are small, they work well. The box was delivered with damage, however, machine was in perfect condition, due to proper protection inside of box. I have told everyone I know, buy this Treadmill. Now I am telling you. Happy Walking.
P.S. I forgot to tell you, I have walked 30 minutes per day, every single day, since I have had this Treadmill. I love it!

I am a 300+ pound middle-aged man with back and leg problems due to a number of blown discs over the years. I have a fair amount of trouble walking, so I wanted to try to increase my coordination and stamina with a treadmill. I was a little skeptical about this product given the price but decided it was worth the risk, given the price of the average "name brand" unit. I'm glad I did.
This thing is rather amazingly solid for something of its size/price. The design is quite clever in its use of leverage to buoy up the overall sturdiness and rigidity; the "C" shape of the floor supports, uprights and grab bars, coupled with the low center of gravity, means that the thing moves around very little during use. It's also pretty quiet: the frame creaked and groaned a little when I first started using it but adjusting the floor shims and skooctching the thing around on the floor a little allowed it to settle in. The grab bars are nice and long, a real necessity in my case. The only other treadmills I found on Amazon with bars of equal or greater length cost a great deal more. Like every treadmill made since the beginning of time, the control panel sits way too far forward of the "upstream" end of the belt....apparently these things are primarily designed for use by people with the arm-length-to-body-height ratio of an orangutan. The little cubbies on either side of the control face are great for storing spare change or perhaps a cigarette lighter, but are useless for anything larger. No big deal, I used Velcro to slap my tablet, stereo remote and other gadgets all over the thing, and you can always zip-tie a holster for a water bottle to the frame somewhere. I'm seriously thinking of disabling the grab-bar-mounted controls, as they are placed where I tend to want to put my hands, but that's going to be different for everyone. Fortunately the controls are joined to the control panel by a wire harness, so I ought to be able to pull the plug on them if I decide I want to.
Amazing, huh? Yes. This is a great product. However, I am deducting two stars for the company's hilariously underwhelming customer service.
In the process of jiggering with the belt tensioners (a tip for new users: if you need to retension the belt, put the belt in its vertical "stored" position first. That way the retensioners are right at eye level, and you can easily look at the whole of the belt while making the adjustments), I overstressed and cracked one of the caps that cover the back ends of the foot rails. They are purely decorative, but I thought I would order a replacement, and while I was at it, ask the customer service representative about the retensioning processâhow tight is too tight, etc. I called the toll-free number (nice touch), and was greeted by the worst, I mean the w o r s t voice-chip phone greeting I have ever heard in my life. If you are a fan of South Park, think of the voice of the "Shake Weight" in that episode. Its cadence and pronunciation were actually a little nauseating to listen to. I'm imagining that the owner of the company bought a turn-key hardware/software telephony package and decided to use the default voice-synth option rather than recording an outgoing message him/herself....bad move. The voice warbled at me that all CSRs were busy and that if I left my name and number someone would get back to me, so I did. Now a week later, and I have yet to hear from anyone....and I even mentioned in my message that I wanted to buy replacement partsâthat is to say, that I wanted to spend more money with them.
This is the dark flip-side of this amazing Information Age in which we live. The ability to asses a company before you buy their wares has diminished considerably. It is entirely possible for a single person to masquerade as a complete business, with all of the attendant infrastructure. Even an impressive Web site is just a matter of a few dollars and several hours' worth of dragging and dropping. I get the feeling that "Paradigm Health & Wellness" is one person sitting in an attached-garage office in a residential neighborhood, with maybe a decommissioned 20-foot shipping container for a "warehouse." I could very well be wrong, but nothing in my experience to date has suggested otherwise.
Would I recommend buying one of these treadmills? Yes, I would; I'm very impressed with mine. But keep the packaging for the first two weeks, and maybe take pictures of the unit as packaged before assembling it so you'll know how to get it back in the box. If you have any issues, you're going to want to avail yourself of Amazon's generous return policy, because I'm not sure you will have any other options.

This treadmill only gets 1-star because of the complete and total lack of customer support from the manufacturer.
The treadmill arrived in a very big and heavy box. The box had some minor scrapes and gouges, but it was heavy-duty cardboard with reinforcements in the corners. There was no damage to the contents.
I was able to unpack and assemble the treadmill with no assistance, but it was a challenge to get it out of the box, especially in the small, crowded living room in which it was going (I'm a 63-year old slightly overweight senior male). The assembly instructions were pretty much worthless, but what little assembly was needed was pretty obvious.
The treadmill seems very well made and sturdy. My wife has been using it for an hour a day for two weeks now without any problems. The motor and belt are very quiet, and it is easy to listen to the TV without having to crank up the volume. The treadmill is short and relatively compact -- a feature we needed -- but neither my wife nor I have any trouble with staying in the main tread area and any of its speeds. The belt is wide and there is plenty of room between the hand rails for arms to swing (and neither of us are skinny). The long side arms do not get in the way, and are essential for my wife who occasionally has some balance problems. The control buttons on the side arms are convenient, and we quickly learned where to position our hands so as to not inadvertently hit them.
The two pockets in the console are worthless. The would be deep enough to hold things like a TV remote or water bottle, but are at such a steep angle that anything put in them vibrates out within seconds when the treadmill is being used. Fortunately, I have a pedal desk (also made by Paradigm Health and Wellness) sitting right next to the treadmill, that has very useful holders for a TV remote and bottle of water.
The treadmill is plastered with very large, obnoxious legal warning stickers that are a ghastly red, orange or yellow. It is impossible to remove the stickers without damaging the paint or plastic parts. It would seem that the manufacturer, Paradigm Health and Wellness, is owned and operated by paranoid lawyers who are certain that anyone who even looks at the treadmill is going to sue them. This treadmill sits in our living room, and these unsightly legal warning stickers are a major eyesore.
The reason for the 1-star review is because my wife called Paradigm's customer support number with a simple question. There is a funny looking symbol on the display with a "T" inside a circle and a number next to it that varies between 19 and 21 during her workout. The mode button and other controls have no effect on this part of the display. The very short owner's manual does not talk about the display at all, and we cannot figure out what "T 19" could possible mean. My wife has tried calling the customer support number in the owner's multiple times and only gets an answering machine telling her to leave a message and a support person will call back. We have not received a call back after two weeks.
I cannot recommend buying a product, no matter how good it is, if the company that makes it does not provide customer support.
UPDATE 3/30/17: We have now had this treadmill for a month. My wife uses it 3 to 4 days a week for 45 minutes each time. After 3 weeks, the treadmill started going berserk. While in use, it would suddenly speed up to its max speed. Holding down the minus button for the speed would slow the treadmill down, but as soon as the button was released it would speed back up again. This would happen several times before the treadmill would final stay at the slower speed. Turning the treadmill off and on, would not help. As soon as it was turned on again, it would race up to its maximum speed. THIS IS A MAJOR SAFETY HAZARD! My wife has leg problems, and cannot walk at the max speed of the treadmill. When it would suddenly speed up, she was be thrown off the back of treadmill more than once if she was not able to step onto the side platforms quickly enough.
I found that the problem is a design and manufacturing defect. The foam tube on the left side hand rail can slide on the steel pipe. The foam had slid down into the speed control switch on the handrail, and caused the UP speed button to stick. I had to loosen the set screw underneath the speed switch, and slide the foam back to its original position (it had only slipped about 1/2 inch). The UP speed button would then function correctly. I have fixed it temporarily by putting a zip-tie around the tube at its furthest forward spot. That has prevented the tube from slipping so far, but the zip-tie end is in the way when holding the railing where it is located.
Other reviewers have reported this same type of failure with this treadmill. The failure should be well-known to the manufacturer, Paradigm Health & Wellness, but they do not seem to be inclined to fix this problem. Paradigm Health & Wellness needs to send customers a proper fix for this problem with the foam tubing slipping before they get SUED!
Paradigm Health customer support has still not responded to my initial call for support, noted in my original review. After 30 days, however, Paradigm Health did send an automated e-mail saying they were closing the support call as being resolved. This company still deserves less than a 1-star review because of their total lack of support and concern for their customers.

About a year ago, I decided to try and change my lifestyle and lose weight. Weighing 341 pounds and on the wrong side of 40, part of my plan included adding exercise to my daily routine. So I bought a treadmill. This treadmill, specifically due to it's competitive price point and it's generous 400-pound weight limit.
One year later, I feel compelled to submit one of the only reviews I've ever submitted for a product on Amazon. I've lost 102 pounds in the last year and this treadmill has been with me on this journey every step of the way. I've beaten the hell out of it, if I'm honest. I think you can imagine the force a 300+ pound man is going to apply on a piece of exercise equipment he's using daily. And the treadmill is clearly showing some wear and tear for sure. The motor is a fair bit louder now than it was back then, the belt squeaks sometimes when you start it up, and occasionally the treadmill will shut down every once in awhile with an "E09" error code that isn't explained in the manual.
But noises and the random error code aside, I can't complain. The frame is still as solid as the day I got it - not even a hint of shake. The motor is still running as good as it ever did. Other than some slight wear along the edges, the belt is in amazingly good shape. I can't speak to the customer service, as I haven't used it. All I can tell you is that this thing is as durable as anything I've ever owned.

Given our experience with this product, I thought I would share it with others.
UPS delivery to your door. Recognize that the box is 60â long, 36â wide and 13â high. It is big. The treadmill itself weighs 120 lbs, add the box and packing material and you are looking at 130 lbs you have to move. You will need two strong people to move the box. If you must go up a stairway (heaven help you), maybe three people. I can see no physical way one person can move this box, put the unit together and then move the unit by themselves. You will need help, someone with muscles and mechanical skills for assembly.
Our box arrived damaged, like someone used a box cutter and cut across the middle of the box. The only obvious damaged was one of the plastic âHandlebar Knobsâ with half the knob you turn broken off. Still usable.
One of the first things you need to decide is whether you will move the unopened box into the room where the treadmill will be located, or assemble the treadmill in say a garage, and then carry the folded treadmill (2 people) to the room. My wife and I messed up and took the box cover off and decided to move the open box to the room. So we needed to use rope around the opened box to hold the unit in the box, raised the box up on its long side, and using towels to protect the floor and ease of sliding, pushed and slid the box into the room where the treadmill was going to be located, about 50 feet from the garage on the same floor. Knowing what I know now, I would have assembled the unit in the garage and then we would have folded the unit as it can be folded, and then carried the folded unit to the room. Live and learn!
Assembly: I would strongly recommend that the ProGear/Paradigm Health and Wellness people bring in customers who are unfamiliar with the unit and watch them follow the âassembly instructionsâ and the problems they encounter. The instructions were obviously written by someone who knows the unit, knows how it goes together. The company needs to bring in people totally unfamiliar with the unit, like two 70 year olds, show them the sealed box and watch what they do and the problems they have, never helping them, then rewrite the assembly instructions and add a few extra diagrams. Step 1 of the instructions is totally worthless. My wife and I, college educated, sat looking at the unit once it was out of the box and could not figure out how to execute the first part of Step 1, âPlace the treadmill in the upright positionâ as it does not show effectively how to expand the unit coming right out of the box. It took us almost an hour of looking and experimenting before we thought we knew what to do. And then a problem occurred with one of the spring-loaded knobs that was jammed in its hole, possibly another result of the damaged box. Step 1 is woefully inadequate to instruct a customer on how to expand the machine out of the box. We believe we have the unit assembled as required, but are not sure given the poor Step 1 instructions.
Steps 2-4 were easy to follow, but the diagram in Step 3 is confusing. It shows that the console and the wires going into the base unit need to be connected. However, our consoleâs wires were already connected. One real challenge, the console sits loose in the box, connected to the base unit only by wires. As you are taking the unit out of the box and expanding it per Step 1, the console is dangling free and we were concerned the connections for the wires, not real robust, would break free. We taped the console to the back handlebar to avoid this, and then removed the tape when we started bolting the console to the console bracket.
Operation and Quality: Once assembled, the unit presents a very strong and sturdy piece of exercise equipment comparable to units 2 or 3 times its cost. The unit began operating as expected, and my wife used it this morning for a full 30-minute walk and had no problems. It is very quiet. You could easily watch TV and walk without having the TV sound turned way up. We did notice that the safety tether is a little short if she walks in the middle of the treadmill. It could have another 6 inches to avoid being disconnected by accident. As a future enhancement, we would ask the manufacturer to add a stop switch on the right handlebar by the speed control. Reaching forward to hit the stop button on the console for people with short arms is a challenge.
If I ignore the assembly challenges, the quality and performance after 1 day are quite good for a $400+ walking treadmill. I would give this unit a rating of 5 stars, but I would give the very poor assembly instructions 1 star. But quality and performance outweigh the temporary assembly issues, the reason for the 4 star rating. Just remember, this is a two person job, moving the box, assembling the unit, and then moving the assembled unit to its final position.

I have never used a treadmill before and didnât think I would. When I would see one at a friends home, it dominated the entire room. But when my husband came home from the hospital he needed to getting moving again so I started to search for a dreaded treadmill. I have been pleasantly surprised by this machine. It is sturdy yet not dominating. It was easy for me a 67 year old lady to assemble (not to easy to move as the box was large and heavy). The suggestion to use the packing materials to help set it up was genius. My husband is using the machine several times a day because I have it behind the sofa. It is shorter than the sofa so we can walk around it easily. I would recommend this model for anyone who needs to get up off the chair and get moving. Itâs safe and reliable.

The worse instruction's manuel for assembly I've ever come across. I think it was written by a 5th grader. I take that back, don't want to insult 5th graders, they could probably do a better job. The drawing illustrations are horrible and very difficult to understand, instructions are confusing and difficult to follow. There are two pieces needed for folding the thread mill, a safety tube and the air piston, and they're not even mentioned in the instructions and how to install them. Had to use common sense to figure it out. The thread mill comes practically unassembled with the exception of the handrails, everything else you have to put together, and with the horrible badly written instructions manuel it was difficult to put together. Good thing I have plenty of experience putting things together which helped me get through it. It's very heavy, and not easy to move around, even when folded for storage, it's still bulky and doesn't maneuver easily. If you're not experienced in putting things together, I wouldn't recommend you attempt this assembly on your own. You need strength, energy, common sense, and patients. The upside, once put together and running, it does operate smooth and very quite, the computer is easy to operate, and the controls button on the handrails to control speed, on/off switch and speed are a nice feature. And by holding the handrails with both hands over the pulse censor, keeps track of your heart rate. It was too bad, I had to have a bad experience with the horrible instructions manuel, and difficulty of putting it together before I could enjoy it.

EDIT 2: I sent an email as directed by the company. I was supposed to get a reply in 3-4 days. After a week I paid to have this piece of junk hauled off because I don't have room to have something this large wasting space in my home. After OVER a week, they contact me, tell me if I ship it back they can refund me (most people aren't going to keep defective and useless products sitting indefinitely). I informed them I just had it shipped of to the dump, was told "oh, nevermind, we assumed you'd keep up junk trashing up your home for a while, bye". Yeah, so their customer support is as horrible as their products. Spend your money elsewhere.
EDIT: Just to include a pic of the broken roller. Treadmill supposed to be rated for 400 lbs, yet 220 lbs caused that breakage so you can figure out yourself based on the weight you're at how much you'd trust it.
With light use, regular maintenance, died about 2 1/2 years in. Which is insanely low for a treadmill (our last one lasted 9 years). Would NOT recommend the brand.
I've been on treadmills that were not motor driven that were more sturdily built. This one didn't even have the guide on it to keep the belt on track (probably what led to the insanely short time before it met an end), so you'd have to constantly adjust the belt one way or the other, even when you got it perfect, next time you use it it would go back off center again and need adjusted. Pathetic.

After about one year I've started having problems with a clacking noise from the back area of the treadmill. I thought maybe loosening the belt could help, but no way. It seems to get louder the faster this treadmill runs. I've gone to the website of my ProGear HCXL 4000 Treadmill where they have "Live Assist". After waiting 15 minutes it appeared no one was mining that area. Also, there does not seem to be a working forum where I can contact other users to see if any are having the same situation and what they do to eradicate the problem. The knocking noise sound serious to me. I'm just hoping the treadmill is not ready to be trashed. I am convinced there is no customer service assist. I have not been able to contact anyone from the company regarding my problem with this treadmill. Has anyone else had a problem with this product and was able to contact customer service? Before I purchased this product, I checked out many of the reviews here and then decided to buy. I am convinced buying a product such as this may not be the best choice. The only way to have repairs done is have someone come to our home since this item is too heavy to load in the SUV. We may have to end up calling our local Salvation Army to come pick this up as a donation. It only held up for one year and that's not good at all.

We have had our treadmill for a little under Six months now and it already doesn't work. I've tried Calling and emailing customer service but they stil haven't responded and it's been 3 days. Make sure you hang on to your owners manual and reveipt. I love the treadmill and this is really disheartening to me. The problem is it won't go off the safe mode. I'll keep this updated as I figure this out.

rev_det.name: Difficult to put together, the belt either slipped or got slowed down under my feet even after adjustment. The belt started and stopped abruptly which tweeked my knee - no smooth transition to full stop. The iFit videos are difficult to find a good one since they are unorganized by intensity or type or length or characteristics. Hr monitor came Broke for mine. How much per month for the videos after free trial??!!!?? No YouTube or Netflix app or any inputs so the screen is useless after a year! Sorry. Not sorry I sent this back.

UPDATE:
I was contacted by the manufacturer's customer service, encouraging me to review the product. In exchange, they offered a floor mat or maintenance kit as a thank you. However, after posting the review they simply ghosted me, reneging on the offer. This feels like a pretty untrustworthy brand now, and I regret the purchase because I dread the day anything goes wrong with the treadmill. A company like this is most assuredly not going to stand by their products when push comes to shove.
Moreover, and unrelated to the terrible customer service, they just pushed an update to their iFit software that FORCES a music player on during your workouts. There is literally no way to stop or remove it. The workaround at the moment seems to be setting the volume to zero and learning to live with the ugly media overlay they added. I cannot for the life of me understand why they'd wreck the experience like that. Why not add a close/remove function?
ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I've very much enjoyed having my NordicTrack Commercial 2450. I use mine primarily for running, primarily in manual workout mode since I have my own training plan.
It was easy to assemble, but it's an incredibly heavy machine. This is good thing for its stability when training on it, but does make it a bit of a workout to assemble it. Definitely *do not* plan to do this by yourself. I did not hire external help to assemble it, which worked out fine (it's not necessary). However, if you don't have access to two fairly strong people, consider paying for assembly.
The reason I've given it 4 rather than 5 stars is that the technology is pretty rough around the edges. If you care deeply about the recorded or live workouts, you may find iFit to need work. You will especially feel this if you are coming from Peleton or equally polished experience. However, it basically works fine so I would not be scared away. Furthermore, at the moment you get a year of iFit for free, so you have ample time to figure out whether it's something you want to use.
The 14-inch screen is totally sufficient for me, especially because I don't use iFit all that often. However, if you *know* you love iFit and have the money, consider an upgrade to the 2950 for a much larger screen. If you don't care about the screen (e.g. you're sure you won't ever use iFit) the 1750 can save you a few hundred dollars. However, it also has a weaker motor, so it's not purely a screen downgrade.

I have owned this treadmill since December 2019. It broke down in April of 2020, so I only used it for 4 months. With this treadmill, I bought the full service maitenance and warranty package. However, it took over 5 months to get it fixed. Then after I got it fixed, it malfunctioned again in early November. I had to contact them three times to get any kind of assistance. Finally, someone said they would order a replacement part. That was over a month ago. I have spent HOURS just on hold with these people only to get hung up on. I have emailed their customer service / help desk SEVEN times. I never received ONE reply or even a status on the part I am supposed to put in myself b/c they can'gt bother to even get someone to do it. Keep in mind, i have not once received one routine maitenance visit the entire time i had this warranty.
They have THE worst customer service. They blame it on COVID, but how does COVID really pfrevent you from people working from home to answer phones? It doesn't. It's a complete joke. They do not care about their customers. Their treadmills break down, and they do not care about fixing or replacing lemon treadmills.
Do NOT buy anything from NordicTrack. Their customer service is completely absent. When you get a hold of someone, they are incredibly rude and callous. They never follow-up with you, and trying to get a hold of someone on the phone takes HOURS, & they usually get disconnected from you conveniently. It's disgusting and completely unacceptable.
BUY A PELOTON!

The tablet would not hold a charge. We worked with ifit support who quickly determined it should be replaced and submitted a parts replacement request for the entire console on 2 September. We have heard nothing since. When we called to check status 3 weeks later we were told, "I don't know what to tell you, the part is on back order. Some people are having to wait others are not. I apologize that I cannot give you any information at this time. I suggest you send an email in a few weeks asking again." This was not a $30 purchase. NordicTrack clearly has an issue with this part or they wouldn't have so many requests and none available. Asked to talk to a manager, of course no one was available. Will never buy NordicTrack again!

Iâve had the treadmill 2450 for 2 weeks. The heart rate sensor grips are very inaccurate, reporting pulse of 45 to 188, jumping all over the place. Did all the recommended troubleshooting. Nordictrack refused to help, repeating that âthe heart rate grip sensors shouldnât be used as a medical device, only gives and average. We cannot improve accuracy. Please use a chest strap etc.â They were even rude to the point of threatening to close the chat if I didnât have any other issue without letting me finish. They did not want to hear the issue I am having with this brand new product. Really? This is an unacceptable response from the manufacturer. I feel that I got a preview of what is to come if the belt or other electrical components start acting up. Expect no support from Nordictrack. I had read about the poor customer service others have had from Nordictrack without truly believing it. Boy was I wrong! Absolute disappointment.
Edit: Also beware of the good reviews. I just received an email from Nordictrack asking me for a good review in exchange for a free matt or maintenance kit. How about fixing my treadmill first?

The First one was damaged on delivery, but this one went together pretty quick (4.5hrs) and easily.
I'd say the only thing that makes this non-Commercial, is the clicking sound it makes while running and
the belt slightly rubbing on something inside the motor housing. Hope it doesn't cause excessive wear. I've elected not to enter my Credit card to gain access to the iFit stuff but there are a few unlocked iFit programs available. Otherwise, this is a great piece of equipment.
Update: Still love this product 6 months later, but would not buy again from Amazon. Six months later, billed me $2118.94 a second time. Their explanation we never scanned the second unit as being returned, even though Amazon sent the truck to pick it up. Didn't want to pay for interest charged to my credit card. Very bad customer service.... don't know how many times they did this so turning my account off.

Seriously, for years I put off buying a treadmill for so many reasons I lost count, but the big ones were up-front cost, space, and my fear that I'd lose interest in it -- way safer to keep a gym membership with a treadmill there, but have other options too. Enter COVID. LOL
I really tried to adapt and just run/walk/hike on my own, but boredom with this dragged on alongside COVID. I looked at used treadmills to save some $$$ but just wasn't finding anything that suited. My last straw was the free iFit trial I got on my phone, just to see how I liked the style/format---figured it'd be too corny for me and that I'd struggle with virtual training (having tried it before), but turns out I liked it more than I thought I would. Global workouts (some relief for the travel-deprived) + personalities + a huge range of workout options was really working for me.
OVERVIEW
Have had this thing a few days now and am freakin' in love with it. I doubt I'll lose interest...even if I cancel iFit after the year trial, the freedom and flexibility I've got with this thing to run/walk anytime I'm free without being hindered by weather, time of day, personal safety, is pretty liberating. I'm just mad it took me this long to get off the fence about getting one in the first place.
MODEL CHOICE
