As a lover of hiking, I looked seriously at NT's incline trainer, but between the primo price and the fact that the deck didn't raise, I dropped back to the Commercial 2450. I actually looked at ProForm too to save some dough since it's the same parent company as NT, but was won over by NT's larger screens and more solid consumer reviews (but would probably be just fine with a ProForm, honestly). Anyway, I don't regret not getting the incline trainer...having done the Waipio Valley hike with Johnnie Gale this morning, 15% incline is plenty...and if that's not burning your calves enough, jack up the speed, lol.
FEATURES
Lots of feature-talk in other reviews so I'll try not to echo too much here...but one complaint by some is that some models were shipped by Amazon without a tray for setting up a tablet in case you want to watch TV or whatnot (since the screen on the trainer won't do that). Mine has the tray, so...wasn't a problem. Fan works fine as a nice cool breeze--thinking of dabbing some essential oil on a cotton ball and taping to the back so I can get some plumeria vibes on the Hawaii training series! LOL! Deck isn't too heavy/hard to raise, but be safe and lift with the legs. The tablet on the trainer has a tilt option, but it's not great, so if you're doing the non-treadmill workouts it can be tough to see. I'd recommend downloading iFit on your phone/tablet and connecting your account there. I haven't noticed any issues between having my account on the trainer and my iPhone. Have had no issues with power/program glitches/freezes/restarts. Fingers crossed it stays that way.
One part I'm still sorting out -- doing manual adjustments to speed/incline in iFit workouts. This is possible, but it does seem buggy sometimes. For example, I'll let the program control the incline, but I might want to adjust speed. If I adjust speed 5-6 times or so, the incline stops auto-adjusting, so I click "follow the trainer" mid-workout as a reset, and start my own adjustments over. This doesn't require stopping the program, and honestly, could be partly user-error. Either way, not a big deal.
SHIPMENT
Like many, I ordered through Amazon b/c the shipping was better than NT's site, where things were on backorder. Given some reviews, I was a little worried though, about damage during transit/delivery. I had zero issue with this, thankfully. I'm wondering if Amazon changed their shipping strategy to account for this b/c I did notice the date I picked for shipping when I ordered got pushed out a week by Amazon. As I tracked things on their site over the days, I noticed the shipment status was vague for over a week before it shipped, and the delivery date changed twice. No one actually contacted me personally via phone to confirm delivery timing/etc., so I contacted Amazon customer service via their chat function. Their agents had more info than what appeared on the site to me which helped. Once it shipped, the email updates came rolling in as to tracking/delivery status. Since they contract the delivery to another company, it wasn't clear at all how to change the delivery date if I had a conflict, but I'm sure if I contacted customer service again, that could get sorted. All told, I ordered the trainer July 31 with an Aug 5 delivery date, but got it on the 11th. If that was the price to pay for COVID and getting it without being damaged, I'll take it. ;)
DELIVERY
Maybe it's b/c I live in a single-story home, but the delivery driver took no issue bringing it across the threshold for me. He even helped me orient it so I had an easier time unboxing.
ASSEMBLY
To be clear, this really is a 2-person job. But I chose to assemble as much as I could solo, then get a friend to help with the rest. Wound up doing the whole thing myself, though I fully appreciate why this isn't the smartest idea, lol. Instructions were pretty clear to me, pieces were neatly organized, and this is one of the few things I've put together where I didn't screw up/misinterpret and have to go back several steps. Bulk aside, I've had worse issues with assembling Ikea shelves, so props to the NT folks on making this clear/easy. And kudos and thanks to those who posted tips in other reviews. Using the box as a sled for getting the deck oriented (I even kept part of the cardboard under the console half of the unit to protect my floor), and assembling in the spot you plan to use it is an absolute must, whether you're assembling yourself or not. This thing has wheels, but wheeling it down the hall to another spot in my home isn't happening. Forget the weight/bulk...based on the direction the wheels are oriented, this thing is too wide for my hallway. I could turn it 90 degrees, but then the wheels are useless so...yes, determine where you want it first, THEN build. Thinking ahead to a situation where you might move residences, one thing I'm considering is taking the entire upper frame off the unit so it can move in 2 pieces (deck + upper frame/console, b/c my main concern would be damaging walls/floors/the unit and especially the console itself). If you don't fully snap in the two plastic pieces that sit over the legs at the base (these plastic pieces are simply cosmetic, and not snapping them in makes zero difference to the look/functionality), you can raise them and access the bolts they cover to unscrew the frame/console...and this absolutely WILL take 2 people...just be sure you disconnect the wire connecting the console to the power supply on the back of the running deck, and safely secure it.

First off - I love this treadmill. For a great price, you get a wide belt, attractive console, and a nice feature set. The treadmill runs quiet. Also, I didnât think that I would like or even use the iFit service, but itâs fabulous! I will likely continue my subscription past the free trial period.
My 2 star rating is because of my horrible experience buying this through Amazon. I Initially bought the treadmill in November as part of a Black Friday deal that included free assembly. Unfortunately, the first treadmill arrived broken - a plastic piece had broken off the hand rail during shipping. The assembly professional had set it up before the damage was realized. Several weeks later and numerous calls with Amazon customer service, the second one finally came. Every step of the way, there was confusion, miscommunication, and poor coordination between Amazon and the third party delivery services which took more phone calls and hours of my time. Then, once the machine was was finally assembled, there was an issue preventing iFit install. An error message kept saying that the treadmill was located out of the US (even though Iâm in Minnesota). More calls - first with iFit, then NordicTrack, then another long call with Amazon. Finally, I got it working myself by installing an update and initiating iFit with a different email account.
It is February, over two months after I ordered the treadmill, and now I can finally enjoy my it. While I received a âgood dealâ from Amazon, it took 8 phone calls with Amazon, coordination with 3 different delivery companies, 2 assembly techs, and 4 missed days of work to be home during the deliveries and pickups. After all of that, I wish I had bought it for full price directly through NordicTrack.

When the unit works properly it is great! We had issues when we originally got it and reported to the company. They said that a replacement part to fix the problem was ordered. Weeks went by with communication! When we followed up they said the part was on back order with no idea when it would be sent! We have contacted multiple times with no resolution! The last call we were told they would send us an email about it. Never received anything! We continue to use the machine and when there are no issues we love it! When issues arise it is not as good. We love the ifit that we have with the unit. We also purchased the warranty plan with the equipment purchase. Would like to get the issue resolved. Without the technical problems the rating would have been higher! Lower rating has to do with lack of the company to solve the technical issue. The company does not stand behind their product!!!!

Got the 2450 in September. Read many reviews, both written and YouTube reviews. Pretty much all ranked NordicTrak the best. Yes, some people have had issues, and many said customer service is very slow. I rolled the dice anyway and bought it.
It took about 30 minutes to get everything out of the box, which was very heavy. It was packed well, with a lot of padding. Be warned, you will have a massive amount of cardboard, styrofoam and wood support pieces to discard. It took me about 3 hours to put it together myself, for the most part. Iâve heard itâs supposed to only take an hour, but it took me 3, for whatever reason. Turned it on, it immediately recognized my wife, and did a software update. Did a test run, and it worked great as advertised.
A few minor gripes, as some others have mentioned. Everything, other than the 2 metal stands that support the console, is plastic. Obviously, plastic can crack if you are not careful. The toe plate absolutely should be metal. Occasionally, my toes slightly hit it. It wouldnât take much to crack that. The console had a slight manufacturing mold defect. The vents that the fan blows air through have some visible defects. Not big enough for me to demand a new console, as you can barely see it, but for $2300, one expects perfection.
The screen is nice, but the operating system is slow...probably Android, but I have no idea. It takes about 1 minute after you turn it on for it to load. IFit is very cool. Dozens of different runs to choose from, from all over the world. Maybe over 100...not sure. They seem to add new ones all the time. You can choose a running one, and just set your speed as you want. You do not have to do the automated speed and inclines. As others have said, the image quality is good, but it buffers at the beginning. It seems to be HD, 1080 maybe, or possibly just 720, but either way, it is certainly compressed. FYI, the 2450 has a 14â screen....pretty decent size. The 1750 only has a 10â screen, which to me is too small for iFit. The 2950 has a huge 22â screen, but itâs an extra $700. And they do have a $4000 treadmill that comes with a monster 32â screen. But as close as you are to it, itâs just too much.
I got a free year of iFit with the purchase. After that, it is $39/mo. Is it worth that much? Not to me. Maybe $15/mo. We got this mainly for the winter months. The other 8 months, we wonât use it much, unless itâs raining outside. You do not need to have iFit to use the treadmill. You can just set the speed and incline/decline. The screen is pretty basic on the manual setting like this. Just a white screen, with an oval shape, plus your speed and a few details. It definitely could be spruced up a bit.
The power cord is at the front right, as is the power button. The way we have ours right up against a wall to the front and the right, it is awkward to plug in and turn on. I just donât want it plugged in unless I am using it...no biggie.
Overall, very happy. Itâs a solid treadmill that does everything as advertised. Zero issues so far, but will cross my fingers. I realize any problems could take a while to resolve. Parts and service calls right now are very slow, from what I hear. Hopefully, I donât have to deal with that for a few years.

First of all, I expected a little more. Maybe I am used to the quality of my Peloton bike, but when I finally got the treadmill put together, it felt like it belonged in the workout room of a Fairfield Inn, rather than the Ritz Carlton equipment I am used to. And the price isn't that much different. The NordicTrack is definitely plasticky and fit is not reflective of a $2500 treadmill.
Got this for my wife for her birthday, and she was underwhelmed as well. She had researched treadmills and thought that this was the ideal one for her, only to find that most basic features are not there. The NT advertises BT compatibility, but it is only one way. You can only play your music through their speakers, not play your workout through headphones. Not great for when we try to do side-by-side workouts together. Also, we expected the iFit to be more like the Peloton classes, having an option for a good, encouraging, MUSIC FILLED workout. The iFit is pretty cheesy with an athelete giving a tour and background of an area. This does not motivate me to work harder at all. We are looking at putting a tablet on top of the screen and running the Peloton running workouts instead.
A lot of people really seem to like this treadmill, but as I said, it definitely falls short of what we were expecting

I'm an avid runner and average around 40-50 mpw. I ordered this treadmill about 10 months ago. I used it 5 day a week during the winter months in MN. The first problem I have encountered (after about 3 months) is the screen over the speakers started rusting, and is now heavily rusted and looks terrible. The shut off key also is rusting. I do sweat but not profusely, and i also wipe it down every time i use it with a dry towel, i keep it inside in a dry environment. The next problem after about 8 months it starts abruptly and stops and will not start again. I've now contacted costumer service and will see how that goes.
I do not recommend this treadmill or any treadmill from Nordic track. I think this product is for some one who wants a great looking machine to just sit in the corner and not be used much.
Update. I called costumer service (this took over 1 1/2 hours on the phone) and they will not cover/replace the rusted screen over the speakers. I also had contact a technician over email help me figure out what was wrong but after a few emails stopped responding to me. This metal screen is defective since it is not painted on both sides and will rust if you get sweat on it. Maybe mine was just missed when it was manufactured but I really doubt it. Costumer service said you need to wipe it down with a soapy towel and a dry towel every time you use it (per the owners manual), which will also cause it to rust since you cant wipe the inside of the screen. SO it is defective and will rust and they will not cover it in the warranty and Nordic Track knows this since they have put these instructions in the owners manual. The main frame tubes are also not painted on the inside and are also rusting. I'll get back and see if they will replace the controller which after talking to the Nordic Track Tec is the other problem, it started to sound like they may not send a replacement even though it is covered by the 12 month warranty They will also not replace the rusty key. This is a cheaply made treadmill and is not worth your $$

The treadmill itself is very well made. Where NordicTrack falls flat is iFit. It is just a terrible experience. Klunky, confusing UI. Too bad too, because the trainers are great. And if you donât want to pay the fee, you literally have one option...an oval track. On top of that, my drive motor began acting up and intermittently starting and stopping. Luckily I am still within the warranty period, but I probably have 100 miles or less. Should not happen on a âcommercialâ treadmill.

I should have returned it when I received a defective unit and they send me a new display sub-assembly to install (5 hour job).
I use the treadmill @ 3 mph for a few hours per week. It is now 7 1/2 months old.
If you do not use/register with Ifit (monthly charge), you may not be able to use the treadmill unless you disconnect wifi and restore the unit to original settings after some software upgrades. Contacted tech support and after a week, they requested my address and serial number (that is already registered with them) then they closed the ticket. Unit still is not able to log on with wifi connected.
Now the drive motor is squeaking loudly. Sent another service request to iconfitness to request service. Found black plastic dust in the bottom of the unit, under the motor. Could not find where it was coming from.
The device name is Commercial 2450. I think the Commercial just means that they advertise it. It is nowhere near commercial quality. Plastic is used to support the lift mechanism.
I won't buy another NordicTrack product. Sad to see such product quality decline.

We used Amazon Services to assemble, which I thought was completely worth it. The guy who came was professional and set it up in 45 minutes. I asked if he had set up this model before and he said he'd set up at least 25 of this model alone recently.
This NordicTrack is perfect for me. Note, that the programming (iFit) has hikes and the treadmill will try to match with the actual experience. So, if you want to feel the steepest of inclines then you may want a treadmill that can do steeper inclines. 15 is good for me. I am VERY glad I got the decline. It's worth the money and sometimes when you jog, its nice to have it be easier without stopping to walk. Something about what it does for you mentally is worth the money. The treadmill is easy to fold and unfold but my 12 year old cant figure it out. Also, you have to be an adult size to really get it down, so it is very child/toddler safe.
Finally, ifit. It comes free, so its easy to ignore what this even is. Without ifit, you get some basic programming and a manual workout that shows a track and your progress around it. iFIT brings this treadmill to life. This is the family plan that comes free, so you can have 5 profiles and it stores your history. The programming is vast and has both live and pre-recorded workouts. Some of the trainers are completely amazing. The workouts span from a walk through pyramids to a jog in Switzerland to training for competitive running.
I highly recommend this product. I only marked a 4 for maneuverability because we havent tried to move it. But it does have wheels and looks manageable.

I purchased this treadmill in March 2020 and it arrived a few weeks later. It was not too difficult to assemble but some of the steps required two people to complete. I also found some of the bolt holes did not line up perfectly which made them difficult to screw in.
Running on the treadmill is great, the deck, even with the softer setting, still seems a bit hard at first but it seems to be getting more cushion the more it is used. If you like a more firmer running surface, the firm setting is very firm.
I was excited about the Ifit functionality, but I've only used it a couple of times and usually run on the manual setting. I do like the fact that each user can have a separate login, so each person can track their own statistics. The screen is large and offers different views depending on how you like to see the details of your run. The quick setting buttons on the side of the console make it easy to change speed and incline, the same buttons on the touch screen are almost impossible to use when running.
The reasons I only rated this treadmill 3 stars: After only 4 months, the lower console buttons stopped working. These consist of the fan, volume, start, stop, speed and incline controls. In addition rust was starting to show up on the front grill that covers the speakers and the two front support posts were being discolored by sweat despite the machine being wiped down after each run. To figure out why the lower console was not working, I unassembled the console section and discovered the ribbon cable going to this area had been discolored and the wires in the cable were damaged.
I reached out to Nordic Track support mid August and began a very slow back and forth email exchange, usually 5 days to a week between their responses. After asking for pictures they agreed to send a replacement console, however a week later it still is showing in progress and has not shipped. It is disappointing that it has taken over 3 weeks and I still have not had a resolution to this problem.
I feel that for a piece of exercise equipment that is wiped down and cleaned after every use, sweat should not affect it so easily. The grill that coverts the speakers can be wiped off, but any sweat that gets into the grill is impossible to clean, just like any sweat that gets into the fan grills is impossible to clean. Support informed me that any visible rust will automatically disqualify a warranty repair/replacement, but they made an exception this time.
I'm glad I purchased the three year warranty as I feel that it will come in handy if the treadmill continues to be affected by sweat caused by using the treadmill.
UPDATE: According to Nordic Track customer support, the console is back ordered and there is no estimate as to when it will ship. This is disappointing and frustrating.
Update2: over one month later and I still have not received the replacement console. No updates from Nordic Track and no ETA on when part will ship. Lowered my star rating to 2 Stars due to this ongoing problem.
Update 3: Finally got the replacement console, after waiting almost 4 months for the replacement. In order to remove the old console and replace it with a new console, you have to dismantle the majority of the upper part of the treadmill.
This treadmill is affected by sweat. Both support posts get stained from sweat, and the grill on the speakers and emergency stop key get rusty from sweat, even when wiped down after each use. I believe the original console stopped working because of sweat getting inside and shorting a wire. I have taken some precautions to reduce the possibility of sweat getting into the console and also rusting the speaker grill, since rust will void the warranty.

Definitely would not recommend this product to anyone. Had to return the first unit as it showed up with the plastic front lower cover broken as the box had obviously been dropped. The front lower cover was cheap thin plastic and the treadmill weighs 340lbs in the box, so it was not surprising it broke when the box was dropped in transit. That was just poor engineering, imho.
The replacement treadmill showed up in better shape, although it was clear the box had also been dropped and was torn up, but other than a small dent nothing appeared broken. We assembled the treadmill and ran into the following problems:
1. Four of the screws for securing the handles to the metal bars would not screw into the pre-drilled holes . I had to get a tap and rethread the screw holes. Same was true of two screws on the top of the upright pillars. That was a needless problem but fixable. But a lot of folks might not know how to rethread the holes.
2. The instructions for booting up the system were very poor. Basically just says to follow the instructions on the screen. Halfway through the setup dialog the system got lost and we ended up having to configure the system by working through the settings rather than using the supposed setup dialog. Could not find any way to restart the setup dialog.
3. The instructions recommended going through the "console tour" to learn how to use the console. As far as we could tell there was no way to access the console tour. It was supposed to show up as part of the setup process but that quit halfway through. We found the software for the unit to be very poor quality in general.
4. The system boots up very very slowly and has a slow response time in general. This is made worse by the fact that you are supposed to log off, turn off the power switch, and then, I kid you not, unplug the treadmill from the wall outlet every time you are done using it. Apparently if you leave the unit plugged in it degrades the electronics, even though they insist you use a surge suppressor. So every time you use the treadmill you have to wait out the long boot up time.
5. When you are jogging on the treadmill and want to get close enough to make changes to speed or incline you will find your feet hitting the bezel on the front of the treadmill. I found myself stumbling when my foot hit the bezel which is a bit dangerous when jogging fast. Very annoying.
6. After we used the unit 5 times the elevation calibration quit working. Called support and sat on hold for an hour and gave up. The iFit and NordicTrack website support was completely useless except that we were finally able to get someone to respond on online chat. They told us either the electronics board or the elevation motor was broken and to call support to get it repaired. Useless as support won't answer the phone.
7. The documentation and user interface were very confusing in terms of differentiating between the basic NordicTrack software and operations vs iFit software and operations. It was also difficult to figure out how to use the iFit software as the user interface was poorly designed and hard to navigate. There were also several software bugs that periodically showed up which compounded the problems.
8. The main reason we chose this unit was the supposed benefits of iFit and the supposed high end treadmill quality. But the iFit software seemed to be largely just a collection of workout videos. There did not appear to be any guidance as to how best to utilize the workout videos to improve your fitness. For the videos we used the narrative in the video was largely the fitness instructor repeating that they were speeding up or down which was pretty useless. In my opinion it would have been better for the instructor to also comment on the area they were walking through and how best to use the videos.
9. On the workout videos we used if you choose to speed up the pace from the default set for the video you have to manually adjust it as the video proceeds rather than the software just adjusting up the speed or incline for you. That was really annoying and a very poor user interface.
10. Basically the software is crap and the support won't answer the phone and the incline electronics were broken and we had had enough and returned the unit.
One last important note. I went to 3 different treadmill review sites and this unit was highly rated on all three. Unfortunately I did not read the negative reviews on Amazon or Consumer Reports. Big mistake as there are some very negative reviews mentioning several of the problems we ran into. It turns out some review sites are fake and have bogus reviews. Leaves me wondering if I got hustled.

I've been on the phone for over an hour trying to register my treadmill and ask a question about banging noise on higher speeds. I can't register on-line because the website is glitching on the device model number and I can't get anyone on the phone. I wonder how long I'll have to wait. Website chat was just as slow, with 31 people waiting in queue in front of me.

Prior to the pandemic I went to the gym several times week. Although i was able to walk and run outside during the spring and summer, it's not as convenient (or appealing) with the weather change and shorter daylight hours. Additionally, in August/ September, working out outside wasn't really an option with the bad air qualify we had in our area due to various ongoing fires. i had been considering a treadmill for a few months and kept coming back to the NordicTrack 2450. Had the features I wanted for a reasonable price.
Assembly - Definitely helpful to have another person to help you. Assembly went pretty smoothly with the exception of lining up the pulse bar when attaching the console. Took a few attempts but everything fit together well. Guessing it took two people a total of approximately 2-3 hours to assemble.
Treadmill - The treadmill feels solid. One feature I definitely wanted was the one-touch incline and speed controls. They are definitely convenient to have. I also like the fact you can adjust the firmness of the deck. (Set mine of softer setting.) The treadmill gets up to speed quickly. Incline adjustments are slower, but can't say it's any slower than most other treadmills I've used. I was able to easily synch my (Orange Theory) heart rate monitor to the treadmill. It's connected each time without any issues. Shortly after I purchased the treadmill, there was a software update that rolled out that allowed me to synch my AirPods too! On average I've been using the treadmill about 4-5x a week.
iFit -I started with a 6 week intro to running series. Great to get me used to running on a treadmill again after having not been on one in over 6 months. The video/ instructor help the workout time pass by pretty quickly. The search/ filter feature on iFit could be a bit better. With all of the various workouts available, it can be a bit daunting to find one that fits your needs/ wants.
Since I was a regular gym goer for 30+ years before purchasing the treadmill, I anticipate the treadmill will continue to get regular use. Working out at home has been super convenient, so at this point I'm not in a rush to return to the gym once they fully reopen. I will likely purchase the service/ protection plan so I can get the treadmill serviced regularly.

The treadmill was amazing for 4 months. I ran an average of 3-6 miles a day. While running the screen turned off and the treadmill is now useless, there is no way to turn it on or us it.
Paid for multiple year warrantyâwaste of money, you are required to go through Norditrack first. Norditrack customer service shows the replacement part as âin progressâ. Apparently if it ever arrives I will have to install it.

Difficult to put together, the belt either slipped or got slowed down under my feet even after adjustment. The belt started and stopped abruptly which tweeked my knee - no smooth transition to full stop. The iFit videos are difficult to find a good one since they are unorganized by intensity or type or length or characteristics. Hr monitor came Broke for mine. How much per month for the videos after free trial??!!!?? No YouTube or Netflix app or any inputs so the screen is useless after a year! Sorry. Not sorry I sent this back.

UPDATE:
I was contacted by the manufacturer's customer service, encouraging me to review the product. In exchange, they offered a floor mat or maintenance kit as a thank you. However, after posting the review they simply ghosted me, reneging on the offer. This feels like a pretty untrustworthy brand now, and I regret the purchase because I dread the day anything goes wrong with the treadmill. A company like this is most assuredly not going to stand by their products when push comes to shove.
Moreover, and unrelated to the terrible customer service, they just pushed an update to their iFit software that FORCES a music player on during your workouts. There is literally no way to stop or remove it. The workaround at the moment seems to be setting the volume to zero and learning to live with the ugly media overlay they added. I cannot for the life of me understand why they'd wreck the experience like that. Why not add a close/remove function?
ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I've very much enjoyed having my NordicTrack Commercial 2450. I use mine primarily for running, primarily in manual workout mode since I have my own training plan.
It was easy to assemble, but it's an incredibly heavy machine. This is good thing for its stability when training on it, but does make it a bit of a workout to assemble it. Definitely *do not* plan to do this by yourself. I did not hire external help to assemble it, which worked out fine (it's not necessary). However, if you don't have access to two fairly strong people, consider paying for assembly.
The reason I've given it 4 rather than 5 stars is that the technology is pretty rough around the edges. If you care deeply about the recorded or live workouts, you may find iFit to need work. You will especially feel this if you are coming from Peleton or equally polished experience. However, it basically works fine so I would not be scared away. Furthermore, at the moment you get a year of iFit for free, so you have ample time to figure out whether it's something you want to use.
The 14-inch screen is totally sufficient for me, especially because I don't use iFit all that often. However, if you *know* you love iFit and have the money, consider an upgrade to the 2950 for a much larger screen. If you don't care about the screen (e.g. you're sure you won't ever use iFit) the 1750 can save you a few hundred dollars. However, it also has a weaker motor, so it's not purely a screen downgrade.

I have owned this treadmill since December 2019. It broke down in April of 2020, so I only used it for 4 months. With this treadmill, I bought the full service maitenance and warranty package. However, it took over 5 months to get it fixed. Then after I got it fixed, it malfunctioned again in early November. I had to contact them three times to get any kind of assistance. Finally, someone said they would order a replacement part. That was over a month ago. I have spent HOURS just on hold with these people only to get hung up on. I have emailed their customer service / help desk SEVEN times. I never received ONE reply or even a status on the part I am supposed to put in myself b/c they can'gt bother to even get someone to do it. Keep in mind, i have not once received one routine maitenance visit the entire time i had this warranty.
They have THE worst customer service. They blame it on COVID, but how does COVID really pfrevent you from people working from home to answer phones? It doesn't. It's a complete joke. They do not care about their customers. Their treadmills break down, and they do not care about fixing or replacing lemon treadmills.
Do NOT buy anything from NordicTrack. Their customer service is completely absent. When you get a hold of someone, they are incredibly rude and callous. They never follow-up with you, and trying to get a hold of someone on the phone takes HOURS, & they usually get disconnected from you conveniently. It's disgusting and completely unacceptable.
BUY A PELOTON!

The tablet would not hold a charge. We worked with ifit support who quickly determined it should be replaced and submitted a parts replacement request for the entire console on 2 September. We have heard nothing since. When we called to check status 3 weeks later we were told, "I don't know what to tell you, the part is on back order. Some people are having to wait others are not. I apologize that I cannot give you any information at this time. I suggest you send an email in a few weeks asking again." This was not a $30 purchase. NordicTrack clearly has an issue with this part or they wouldn't have so many requests and none available. Asked to talk to a manager, of course no one was available. Will never buy NordicTrack again!

Iâve had the treadmill 2450 for 2 weeks. The heart rate sensor grips are very inaccurate, reporting pulse of 45 to 188, jumping all over the place. Did all the recommended troubleshooting. Nordictrack refused to help, repeating that âthe heart rate grip sensors shouldnât be used as a medical device, only gives and average. We cannot improve accuracy. Please use a chest strap etc.â They were even rude to the point of threatening to close the chat if I didnât have any other issue without letting me finish. They did not want to hear the issue I am having with this brand new product. Really? This is an unacceptable response from the manufacturer. I feel that I got a preview of what is to come if the belt or other electrical components start acting up. Expect no support from Nordictrack. I had read about the poor customer service others have had from Nordictrack without truly believing it. Boy was I wrong! Absolute disappointment.
Edit: Also beware of the good reviews. I just received an email from Nordictrack asking me for a good review in exchange for a free matt or maintenance kit. How about fixing my treadmill first?

The First one was damaged on delivery, but this one went together pretty quick (4.5hrs) and easily.
I'd say the only thing that makes this non-Commercial, is the clicking sound it makes while running and
the belt slightly rubbing on something inside the motor housing. Hope it doesn't cause excessive wear. I've elected not to enter my Credit card to gain access to the iFit stuff but there are a few unlocked iFit programs available. Otherwise, this is a great piece of equipment.
Update: Still love this product 6 months later, but would not buy again from Amazon. Six months later, billed me $2118.94 a second time. Their explanation we never scanned the second unit as being returned, even though Amazon sent the truck to pick it up. Didn't want to pay for interest charged to my credit card. Very bad customer service.... don't know how many times they did this so turning my account off.

Seriously, for years I put off buying a treadmill for so many reasons I lost count, but the big ones were up-front cost, space, and my fear that I'd lose interest in it -- way safer to keep a gym membership with a treadmill there, but have other options too. Enter COVID. LOL
I really tried to adapt and just run/walk/hike on my own, but boredom with this dragged on alongside COVID. I looked at used treadmills to save some $$$ but just wasn't finding anything that suited. My last straw was the free iFit trial I got on my phone, just to see how I liked the style/format---figured it'd be too corny for me and that I'd struggle with virtual training (having tried it before), but turns out I liked it more than I thought I would. Global workouts (some relief for the travel-deprived) + personalities + a huge range of workout options was really working for me.
OVERVIEW
Have had this thing a few days now and am freakin' in love with it. I doubt I'll lose interest...even if I cancel iFit after the year trial, the freedom and flexibility I've got with this thing to run/walk anytime I'm free without being hindered by weather, time of day, personal safety, is pretty liberating. I'm just mad it took me this long to get off the fence about getting one in the first place.
MODEL CHOICE
As a lover of hiking, I looked seriously at NT's incline trainer, but between the primo price and the fact that the deck didn't raise, I dropped back to the Commercial 2450. I actually looked at ProForm too to save some dough since it's the same parent company as NT, but was won over by NT's larger screens and more solid consumer reviews (but would probably be just fine with a ProForm, honestly). Anyway, I don't regret not getting the incline trainer...having done the Waipio Valley hike with Johnnie Gale this morning, 15% incline is plenty...and if that's not burning your calves enough, jack up the speed, lol.
FEATURES
Lots of feature-talk in other reviews so I'll try not to echo too much here...but one complaint by some is that some models were shipped by Amazon without a tray for setting up a tablet in case you want to watch TV or whatnot (since the screen on the trainer won't do that). Mine has the tray, so...wasn't a problem. Fan works fine as a nice cool breeze--thinking of dabbing some essential oil on a cotton ball and taping to the back so I can get some plumeria vibes on the Hawaii training series! LOL! Deck isn't too heavy/hard to raise, but be safe and lift with the legs. The tablet on the trainer has a tilt option, but it's not great, so if you're doing the non-treadmill workouts it can be tough to see. I'd recommend downloading iFit on your phone/tablet and connecting your account there. I haven't noticed any issues between having my account on the trainer and my iPhone. Have had no issues with power/program glitches/freezes/restarts. Fingers crossed it stays that way.
One part I'm still sorting out -- doing manual adjustments to speed/incline in iFit workouts. This is possible, but it does seem buggy sometimes. For example, I'll let the program control the incline, but I might want to adjust speed. If I adjust speed 5-6 times or so, the incline stops auto-adjusting, so I click "follow the trainer" mid-workout as a reset, and start my own adjustments over. This doesn't require stopping the program, and honestly, could be partly user-error. Either way, not a big deal.
SHIPMENT
Like many, I ordered through Amazon b/c the shipping was better than NT's site, where things were on backorder. Given some reviews, I was a little worried though, about damage during transit/delivery. I had zero issue with this, thankfully. I'm wondering if Amazon changed their shipping strategy to account for this b/c I did notice the date I picked for shipping when I ordered got pushed out a week by Amazon. As I tracked things on their site over the days, I noticed the shipment status was vague for over a week before it shipped, and the delivery date changed twice. No one actually contacted me personally via phone to confirm delivery timing/etc., so I contacted Amazon customer service via their chat function. Their agents had more info than what appeared on the site to me which helped. Once it shipped, the email updates came rolling in as to tracking/delivery status. Since they contract the delivery to another company, it wasn't clear at all how to change the delivery date if I had a conflict, but I'm sure if I contacted customer service again, that could get sorted. All told, I ordered the trainer July 31 with an Aug 5 delivery date, but got it on the 11th. If that was the price to pay for COVID and getting it without being damaged, I'll take it. ;)
DELIVERY
Maybe it's b/c I live in a single-story home, but the delivery driver took no issue bringing it across the threshold for me. He even helped me orient it so I had an easier time unboxing.
ASSEMBLY
To be clear, this really is a 2-person job. But I chose to assemble as much as I could solo, then get a friend to help with the rest. Wound up doing the whole thing myself, though I fully appreciate why this isn't the smartest idea, lol. Instructions were pretty clear to me, pieces were neatly organized, and this is one of the few things I've put together where I didn't screw up/misinterpret and have to go back several steps. Bulk aside, I've had worse issues with assembling Ikea shelves, so props to the NT folks on making this clear/easy. And kudos and thanks to those who posted tips in other reviews. Using the box as a sled for getting the deck oriented (I even kept part of the cardboard under the console half of the unit to protect my floor), and assembling in the spot you plan to use it is an absolute must, whether you're assembling yourself or not. This thing has wheels, but wheeling it down the hall to another spot in my home isn't happening. Forget the weight/bulk...based on the direction the wheels are oriented, this thing is too wide for my hallway. I could turn it 90 degrees, but then the wheels are useless so...yes, determine where you want it first, THEN build. Thinking ahead to a situation where you might move residences, one thing I'm considering is taking the entire upper frame off the unit so it can move in 2 pieces (deck + upper frame/console, b/c my main concern would be damaging walls/floors/the unit and especially the console itself). If you don't fully snap in the two plastic pieces that sit over the legs at the base (these plastic pieces are simply cosmetic, and not snapping them in makes zero difference to the look/functionality), you can raise them and access the bolts they cover to unscrew the frame/console...and this absolutely WILL take 2 people...just be sure you disconnect the wire connecting the console to the power supply on the back of the running deck, and safely secure it.

First off - I love this treadmill. For a great price, you get a wide belt, attractive console, and a nice feature set. The treadmill runs quiet. Also, I didnât think that I would like or even use the iFit service, but itâs fabulous! I will likely continue my subscription past the free trial period.
My 2 star rating is because of my horrible experience buying this through Amazon. I Initially bought the treadmill in November as part of a Black Friday deal that included free assembly. Unfortunately, the first treadmill arrived broken - a plastic piece had broken off the hand rail during shipping. The assembly professional had set it up before the damage was realized. Several weeks later and numerous calls with Amazon customer service, the second one finally came. Every step of the way, there was confusion, miscommunication, and poor coordination between Amazon and the third party delivery services which took more phone calls and hours of my time. Then, once the machine was was finally assembled, there was an issue preventing iFit install. An error message kept saying that the treadmill was located out of the US (even though Iâm in Minnesota). More calls - first with iFit, then NordicTrack, then another long call with Amazon. Finally, I got it working myself by installing an update and initiating iFit with a different email account.
It is February, over two months after I ordered the treadmill, and now I can finally enjoy my it. While I received a âgood dealâ from Amazon, it took 8 phone calls with Amazon, coordination with 3 different delivery companies, 2 assembly techs, and 4 missed days of work to be home during the deliveries and pickups. After all of that, I wish I had bought it for full price directly through NordicTrack.

When the unit works properly it is great! We had issues when we originally got it and reported to the company. They said that a replacement part to fix the problem was ordered. Weeks went by with communication! When we followed up they said the part was on back order with no idea when it would be sent! We have contacted multiple times with no resolution! The last call we were told they would send us an email about it. Never received anything! We continue to use the machine and when there are no issues we love it! When issues arise it is not as good. We love the ifit that we have with the unit. We also purchased the warranty plan with the equipment purchase. Would like to get the issue resolved. Without the technical problems the rating would have been higher! Lower rating has to do with lack of the company to solve the technical issue. The company does not stand behind their product!!!!

Got the 2450 in September. Read many reviews, both written and YouTube reviews. Pretty much all ranked NordicTrak the best. Yes, some people have had issues, and many said customer service is very slow. I rolled the dice anyway and bought it.
It took about 30 minutes to get everything out of the box, which was very heavy. It was packed well, with a lot of padding. Be warned, you will have a massive amount of cardboard, styrofoam and wood support pieces to discard. It took me about 3 hours to put it together myself, for the most part. Iâve heard itâs supposed to only take an hour, but it took me 3, for whatever reason. Turned it on, it immediately recognized my wife, and did a software update. Did a test run, and it worked great as advertised.
A few minor gripes, as some others have mentioned. Everything, other than the 2 metal stands that support the console, is plastic. Obviously, plastic can crack if you are not careful. The toe plate absolutely should be metal. Occasionally, my toes slightly hit it. It wouldnât take much to crack that. The console had a slight manufacturing mold defect. The vents that the fan blows air through have some visible defects. Not big enough for me to demand a new console, as you can barely see it, but for $2300, one expects perfection.
The screen is nice, but the operating system is slow...probably Android, but I have no idea. It takes about 1 minute after you turn it on for it to load. IFit is very cool. Dozens of different runs to choose from, from all over the world. Maybe over 100...not sure. They seem to add new ones all the time. You can choose a running one, and just set your speed as you want. You do not have to do the automated speed and inclines. As others have said, the image quality is good, but it buffers at the beginning. It seems to be HD, 1080 maybe, or possibly just 720, but either way, it is certainly compressed. FYI, the 2450 has a 14â screen....pretty decent size. The 1750 only has a 10â screen, which to me is too small for iFit. The 2950 has a huge 22â screen, but itâs an extra $700. And they do have a $4000 treadmill that comes with a monster 32â screen. But as close as you are to it, itâs just too much.
I got a free year of iFit with the purchase. After that, it is $39/mo. Is it worth that much? Not to me. Maybe $15/mo. We got this mainly for the winter months. The other 8 months, we wonât use it much, unless itâs raining outside. You do not need to have iFit to use the treadmill. You can just set the speed and incline/decline. The screen is pretty basic on the manual setting like this. Just a white screen, with an oval shape, plus your speed and a few details. It definitely could be spruced up a bit.
The power cord is at the front right, as is the power button. The way we have ours right up against a wall to the front and the right, it is awkward to plug in and turn on. I just donât want it plugged in unless I am using it...no biggie.
Overall, very happy. Itâs a solid treadmill that does everything as advertised. Zero issues so far, but will cross my fingers. I realize any problems could take a while to resolve. Parts and service calls right now are very slow, from what I hear. Hopefully, I donât have to deal with that for a few years.

I bought the NordicTrack 2450 Commercial in August 2020. The treadmill was working well until two weeks ago when it suddenly stopped working. After two days of trying to reach someone in Icon Fitness Customer Service Department to help me, I managed to get through. They asked me to send a video explaining the problem. The Customer Service Rep determined that the motor is broken and put in a order to replace it. Two weeks later I'm still waiting for the motor to arrive. When I try to check the order status on the Icon Fitness website I get no information on my order. Now I have a huge heavy $2500 piece of junk in my house. Terrible experience!

I love my Nordic Track, I love the fact that it has a big tablet mounted on, my only pet peeve is, I want to be able to use it as a tablet, so that I can watch a movie when I'm working out, I want to use it as a tablet so that I can read a book on Kindle, I want to be able to use my iphone to control the speed and the incline, I own a different treadmill that is smaller in size but it does have remote access through an app on my phone.
The workouts Nordic Track has are wonderful, the manual mode is what I use, still, I wish I could just place a laptop over the top of the Nordic Track screen, only, I can't do that because how do I know what my progress is, my laps, my heart rate, my calories, the time i am spending on it. It is way too big for my bedroom and it looks gigantic in my living room, if you have a ceiling fan in the middle of the living room like me, don't even try to stretch out while on the Nordic Track 2450, you will hit that ceiling fan really fast. It is tall, it is heavy, the box, the Styrofoam, the 4x4s that the treadmill comes packed in are going to cost you to have the Waste management company remove them, it didn't cost me because it happened to be during a citywide clean-up and it was free, but someone mentioned that where they live, it costs money to get rid of the waste. Also, it is difficult to assemble the treadmill by yourself, you need to have someone help you but when you are a loner like me, you are going to get pretty inventive, because the hydraulic arm that holds the platform up does not come fully assembled. I purchased a different treadmill before I purchased my Nordic Track and it almost came ready to use, two steps and I was done, not with Nordic Track, but that's why they are a renowned company that doesn't make junk. Thank you Nordic Track.

I am very happy with this purchase and highly recommend it.
I didn't intend to use the iFit video training stuff much. Turns out that is one of my favorite things about the treadmill. There is some gorgeous scenery and the different trainers enhance my desire to train longer or more frequently. I am more motivated because of the iFit system. There are "videos" of different places that one can watch while running without a trainer. Unfortunately those, instead of being actual videos, are multiple still photographs that lurch forward. Disappointed in them.
It is fairly quiet, all things considered. With the preset buttons for different speeds and inclines it is easy to switch back and forth during intervals. The fan is very powerful. That will be handy when it's warm. In the winter when I would get slightly sweaty, the fan was sometimes too powerful. Wish it had more gradations in adjustment.
I don't run outside much any more - it hurts my knees sometimes, and my lower back almost always. (Abdominal obesity induced lumbar lordosis). Running on the treadmill, with the suspension system turned on, has not caused me ANY joint pains. I try to run at a 3% incline usually as I've read that further decreases joint impact.
I had trouble getting my Polar H10 hr sensor to sync. It turned out the H10 can only sync with 1 thing at a time BUT if you use the Polar Beat app you can go into hr sensor settings and turn on the option of syncing two things with the HR sensor.
I put it on carpet after studying all the mat and foam options. The front of the machine's weight is well distributed across the frame work, not just the wheels. The rear did begin to indent the carpet. I went to Lowes and bought some sheet metal type stuff that doesn't bend and yet is thin and put them under the rear legs. The metal was from the section of metal used to mesh or tie together wood. Because it's thin the metal doesn't affect the accuracy of the incline.
Great machine, a solid part of my fitness program, regardless of the weather!

I have been very happy so far with this purchase. I absolutely love using the IFit program and will mostly likely renew it after my free year. There are so many options to choose from and I love that the treadmill automatically adjusts as you complete a workout.
As far as the actual treadmill goes, it was fairly easy to assemble but very heavy so we needed some extra muscle to carry the boxes upstairs. Once assembled, setup was also pretty easy and I was able to jump on and try it out very quickly.
I love the steep incline and also the option to decline. The motion is smooth and comfortable. The fans are a nice feature and very much welcomed when the workouts get intense! Controls are easy to use and adjust. The screen is a perfect size.I have no complaints. This machine has given me the extra push to get up and exercise and the IFit options keep me coming back each day for something new,

So I purchased this product in September of 2020, like most of you our Gym was closed so I was looking for a high quality product that I could use on a regular basis. Everything seemed good at first, the tread arrived on time and was easy enough to assemble but unfortunately the last three weeks have been a nightmare. I really enjoy the streaming videos but starting about 3 weeks ago my tablet started buffering and became unusable.
I've tried everything that I can think of including reconfiguring my wireless network, resetting the tablet to factory settings etc. Nothing has worked. The customer support at Nordictrack is useless. They are yet to reach out to me proactively and they continue to blame my network. Mind you I'm running Gig Internet and I'm streaming all over the house with zero issues. I've had two of the reps I've spoken with admin that they are tired, overworked and short staffed. Here's the best part. I bought a Peloton bike around the same time and it's literally sitting next to my tread and it never ever buffers. Same type of tablet and it's running three times the speed that the tread tablet is running at.
It's obviously a problem that the Nordictrack reps don't want to have to deal with so today I'm returning this thing and buying a Peloton tread. After all, I've been running the Peloton tread workouts on the TV in my garage for the last three weeks (off of my Wifes bike account through a Roku stick) and they are fantastic. And they never buffer by the way.

I'm a very active runner who was skeptical about how sturdy a $2K treadmill would be. But, when this summer's fires made air quality abysmal, I but the bullet and purchased the 2450. I was even further skeptical that Nordicktrack calls the units 'commercial 2450', because I know true commercial treadmills cost much more. In addition, this model is 40ish pounds lighter than other treadmills in its price class. But...I have been very pleasantly surprised. 1) This holds up absolutely fine not only for normal daily runs but also for mile/half-mile repeats ~10-11mph, 2) Assembly was much easier than I expected. Instructions are actually easy to follow (shocking I know) and I was able to assemble it on my own despite the note that 2 people are required. My daughter gave me a couple 2-min assists when having another hand was useful. 3) While I have no complaints about the ifit stuff, I generally prefer to craft my own workouts. And, the statistics layout (including vertical gain) is really good. This was probably the main reason I went for Nordicktrack over Peloton. They both have programmed/studio workouts but I am old school and picked what I thought was better for feeding my data needs when running without those programs. I am not disappointed. 4) The frills are pretty good....speaker quality, fan, console layout. My only concern was the package in which the treadmill was delivered was seriously messed-up...torn and taped back together. I'd read that in other reviews as well, and that fed some of my initial skepticism. Fortunately, nothing was damaged so it was a non-issue. I would caution that the package is also seriously heavy (despite being lighter than some other treadmills). It's only one box for ~300lbs. Plan on having family and friends available, especially if you decide you want this to go up a flight of stairs before you assemble. But, all in all...I am quite happy with this purchase.

A fantastic treadmill! I love the automatic adjustment for the incline and decline during workouts, the ifit membership with tons of workouts to choose from, the size of the screen, and the sturdiness of this treadmill. It is the level of quality you would find at a gym and has really helped me take my workouts to the next level at home. One thing to remember is to have at least 2 people put it together as it is very heavy (as noted on the packaging and instructions).

This has been the most disappointing purchase we have ever made. After only 4 months and 400 miles, the walking platform cracked down the middle and made the instrument unusable. We placed a warranty request and a replacement part has been ordered, but this was two weeks ago and it still hasn't shipped. I highly suggest getting the extended warranty, we were lucky ours was still covered. I hope we are not having to replace the walking platform every 4 months, it is not an easy part to remove/replace. They are also not offering any labor support to repair the instrument. You are on your own once you get the part....
I would look elsewhere for a treadmill. We went with Nordictrack because of the good reviews and reputation, but never again. We had a ProForm with 1000s of miles that was over 10 years old and still working. We only replaced it to get some of the more modern features. I regret not sticking with that company.

I was excited to receive this treadmill. Unfortunately, it came with a missing part, and it was near impossible to get in touch with customer service. It took over 4 months (!) to receive the missing part from NordicTrack. In the interim, I had purchased the part from a third party, and Amazon reimbursed me for it.
The treadmill is very noisy, but I gave up on trying to have NordicTrack help me figure out the source or normalcy of the noise. I even purchased an extended warranty with annual visits that is unlikely to be used given how impossible it is to receive service through NordicTrack.
I'm disappointed with the tread, but even more so with the customer service experience. iFit and ActivePulse are great and enjoyable, but ICON Fitness has a lot of work to do if it wants to retain customers that otherwise will make the jump to Peloton and other fitness brands that provide for an easier installation/delivery experience and much more responsive customer service.
After I bought this treadmill, I also purchased a NordicTrack S22i bike from Amazon. The bike was defective and unusable. To this day, NordicTrack hasn't responded to my messages or called me to remediate the issue. I finally returned the bike through Amazon's stellar customer service and was rid of it. I purchased a Peloton Bike+ instead, and it's been a night and day experience all around.
I also purchased a NordicTrack Vault directly through NordicTrack and haven't had any issues with it. Thankfully, because I wouldn't know whom to turn to other than my credit card company.
NordicTrack equipment is solid and iFit is a bit frustrating to use but good when it works (it is lightyears behind robust apps like the Peloton app in terms of usability). Be aware that NordicTrack doesn't provide the customer service experience one would expect of a company of its size.

This is the best treadmill weâve ever owned and maybe even superior to the ones at the gym. It has a decline to simulate walking downhill and an incline of up to 12. This is perfect for home-made âhikes." The built-in fan, huge screen and Bluetooth music capability are all major bonuses. The machine is sturdy with a comfortable deck (even for my husband coming off of hip surgery). The treadmill is also pretty quiet for its size. It has holders on the left and right of the screen for water bottles and accessories, but also plenty of room below to hold hand weights. I am thankful they made a high quality large treadmill that still folds, which is needed for real life. The iFit has been fun to explore. We especially like how the treadmill will automatically follow the trainer and adjust to match her workout. It's extremely FUN walking/running all over the world!!! Our teens love just being able to jump on the treadmill and take a class whenever they want and have their own individual iFit accounts to track their performance. They are loving the "competition."
This one is a 5-Star guarantee for all!!!

The box was destroyed when delivered. It weighs 400 lbs. The parts are bent and scratched. He assembly was difficult, took 2 hours to assemble. The machine works well so far. Nice screen. Fan is nice. Pretty quiet. IFit is super cool. I wish I could access Netflix or other apps but thatâs ok.

My family uses our treadmill a great deal, especially during the pandemic and the dark and cold winter months. We were therefore disheartened when our Precore treadmill died after eight years of no-fuss performance. We decided to go with the NordicTrack Commercial 2450 as a replacement even though it was substantially more expensive than many alternatives because we wanted something sturdy and it was available for quick delivery. BIG MISTAKE!
First, it was an enormous chore putting it together. It took our genius handyman almost three hours of hard work to get it up and running. Second, the IFit "free-for-a-year" classes are terrible. We use a Peloton bike and their programming and there is simply no comparison on quality of instructor, production and engagement. IFit stinks.
But we would have sucked all of this up and not written this review except for our third problem: our machine puts out a loud and irritating beep no matter what we do. The fact that the heart-monitor pads don't work is a very minor irritant in comparison.
We've complained to NordicTrack for weeks and after a significant delay, we finally had someone reach out to see what is wrong. They asked for a video of the problem, which we sent, and we once again have heard nothing back. We are frustrated enough that we tried to return the treadmill to NordicTrack only to learn that we can't do that directly since we bought it through Amazon.
A word to the wise - don't buy this product!

Wish I had bought a different model, not pleased. The iFit software is slow, clunky, it would not let me register, and it feels very cheap. There is no way for you to access the machine without going through the iFit software interface. If you want to just jump on your treadmill and go, plan to futz with software first and a forced warm up, etc. itâs like a nanny state treadmill.
The physical treadmill itself is just OK. It honestly feels a lot cheaper than what they used to make and the controls are restrictive.
Iâm going to sell this locally at a loss and just start all over again. ~sigh

I ordered the NordicTrack 2450 14" Treadmill for $1999 in September. I think they lost the first one, as it never arrived. After calling a few times, they sent a replacement and it finally arrived start of November.
This is the first treadmill I've owned or used and don't have a basis for comparison, but I do love it and have used it every day since it arrived 6 weeks ago.
Assembly was fairly easy. I managed to put it together in about an hour and only needed my wife to assist for a few minutes at the end. Note that it is very heavy - if you can, have the delivery people put it where you are going to assemble it.
All the controls (incline, speed, volume) seem to be well placed and easy to reach (I'm 5' 10"). I find it comfortable for walking and running - no complaints there. It runs quiet, but the motor to raise and lower the incline can be loud and annoying.
I spent the first few weeks going through the included (free) iFit workouts and did some multiple times before signing up for the one year trial. This provided a good preview of what's available within the iFit app and lets you see which trainers you may like. Overall, I really like the iFit app and find it very motivational. I was expecting it to be just videos of scenic places but it provides much more than I expected - it's sort of like going for a run with a friend who talks to you the whole time and tells you interesting facts about the area, people, culture, etc. The speed and incline adjusts automatically with the video but can be overridden if you want to go faster/slower or raise/decrease the incline.
The 14" screen is adequate. I sort of wish I went larger, but overall, I'm pretty happy with this purchase.

When it's delivered, it's huge! We unpacked it outside and brought it inside piece by piece. The unpacking and assembly took a couple hours. We took our time. Most of it went together easily. Attaching the control panel/monitor piece was the hardest part to get lined up. We did our best. I suspect the grips aren't working properly and that'd be my guess as to why. I'm enjoying the ifit workouts but have no plan to renew once the free year is up because it's so expensive. So far the machine seems sturdy. It loses wifi connection from time to time even though other devices are fine. If you use manual mode, it shows a track with your progress. They should make it possible to hook up to the internet. (But then why would you need ifit I guess) I'm glad I got it though. I've had it about a month now.

It turns out I need someone to push me to work harder during my workouts. I have had personal trainers in person and if COVID did not exist and money was no option I would continue paying several hundred dollars per month for 1-on-1 sessions and a gym membership.
During COVID I decided to purchase the treadmill to help curb the calories. I was surprised to learn that iFit, the application and service that runs on the treadmill is exactly what I needed. Turns out it doesn't matter whether the personal trainer is a person or a virtual one, I was able to get motivated in a similar way. On top of that I enjoy the different scenery and choice of trainers available.
If you are a purist when it comes to working out, the iFit service might not be for you, I know that some hard core trainers have not given it good ratings for one reason or another. But for me (and probably for most folks), it works, and it keeps me coming back.
No more gym for me, this thing does what I need. Keep in mind when considering your options that iFit has a reoccurring service charge - nothing in this world is free!

The item was defective upon receipt. It made loud screeching noises and creeking noises when you were on the belt. We tried to troubleshoot with NordicTrack who felt it was a âlubeâ issue with the belt. We allowed them to send lube for us to put under the belt but we knew the defect was inside the base of the treadmill. It was a lost cause from the start. We took it apart and sent it back. I never even got to use it. My husband maybe got one or two walks/runs in but the loud noises coming from it were not something we could tolerate. It wasnât ok for me to have somebody come out to try and fix it on an item that was defective from the get go. I am waiting on my refund. We paid over $2,400 for an item that was carelessly manufactured. In the age of Covid, itâs likely the manufacturer is mass producing these items and there isnât a lot of quality control in place.

Update to my last review
I received a replacement controller board from Icon Fitness (they are customer service group) - put it in , and you guessed - same problem - doesn't work. The dreaded 4 blinks on the board
I will be filing a complaint with the Better Business Bureau
Do NOT but these treadmills - defective treadmills with defective replacement parts (garbage from China)
I am furious and out over 2K -- and had the treadmill a mere 5 months
Oh, a customer service ? If you can get them on the line they try hard to sell the extended warranty - wonder why?

The treadmill broke after six months and less than 100 miles. We didnât use it all Summer. Then in the Fall it started making a terribly loud banging in the motor box. We contacted Icon Health Fitness the warranty company. They were absolutely no help. They wanted us to take the motor apart and remove the drive belt and take a video of it running. I didnât pay for a warranty so I could take the motor apart. I donât recommend this Nordic Track treadmill and would never do business with Icon Health Fitness

I have only had this for a week now so I'll review based on limited experience and update if needed.
Box arrived few days later than planned. It arrived to the delivery company on the day prescribed, but then took two days beyond that to get to my home. The box was mangled and the delivery company noted that on the delivery slip. My main floor is essentially a second story because I have a daylight basement. I opened the box in the driveway and brought in the parts I could lift alone. No issues due to the box mangling. Seems very well packed to prevent any major issues in transit. I did need a friend to help bring the running deck in. It's heavy, but easily managed with two people.
Assembly took about two hours. The instructions and relevant needed parts packaging are very good. I can see where people have issues if they don't fully read the instructions about not tightening certain bolts, but if you actually read what's written, it's all pretty simple. At the end, go back and tighten everything up and it's all good.. Assembly says it needs two people, but its easy enough with just one.
I didn't sign up for the iFit stuff despite having the year free. Just felt it was over priced and unnecessary for my needs. Not sure why people say you have to sign up for it....it was easily skipped during set up.

The NordicTrack 2450 Treadmill is a wonderful piece of equipment. I'm an endurance runner with a larger frame, and I put my equipment to the test. After 6 weeks of heavy use, my 2450 is humming right along with zero issues. The sturdy frame and cushioned tread make for a comfortable run. I utilize the iFit technology to guide my training series', and I love how it provides an opportunity to follow some of my favorite athletes and trainers all over the world. Once you login and choose your workout, the machine does the rest. It automatically controls your speed and incline, and of course you have the option to manually control it as well if that's better for you. The 14" touchscreen on this machine has excellent clarity and size, and the speakers give off solid sound. The fan is powerful and easy to control. The one touch speed and incline are great as well for my manual workouts. The unit folds-up very easily with the included hydraulic support lift, and is equally as easy to let back down. Assembly took about 2 hours for my wife and I to complete. The directions were satisfactory and we did not have any issues. This machine is of commercial quality and is therefore very heavy. I use it on the second story of my house, and it took 3 grown men to get it up the stairs and to its final location, so keep that in mind. The noise level below when I am running, even at high speeds, is minimal. This is a fantastic piece of equipment, and it has helped me to make great progress in my distance running and overall fitness. I intend to keep it for many years to come.

Was looking at Threadmills for about 1-2 months. Was looking at model below this one until I saw this model on sale with Amazon for basically the same price I could get the 1750 model. Wife and I use it 5-6 times a week each since we purchased it and really enjoy it.
While it's easy to fold we never fold it since we are working out daily on it. Assembly was a little rough since it was only my wife and I and delivery was to threshold of home and we unpacked it within the garage and moved the pieces individually to our sunroom were we set it up. The hardest part to move was the base itself.
But we are very pleased with this purchase. It goes from -3% to 15% incline which is plenty for us. Top speed is 12mph which neither one of us will ever use.

We have had it for a month. Been working with insurance because it does not incline. It has a bad motor that they are sending a new one that I have to install. I haven't got to use the ifit program yet. Only ran on it on manual mode so it doesn't incline and mess up the motor. I'm glad I bought insurance or I'd be s.o.l right now.
Over all we got the 14 inch screen which is perfect. The program you can use if you have a rowing machine or bike. We don't have the nordictrack ones but the program still works. I just hope to get this fixed because I bought this for the incline and program that goes with it. Right now it's just an ordinary tredmill.

I've done a lot of running on treadmills in gyms and this one is way nicer than most. I also got the IFit membership for one year and its been keeping me motivated! I had a technician put it together for me and it was well worth not putting my husband through the aggravation. The monitor is a nice size and tilts down if your short like me and has a fan for cooling (bonus). Being stuck home in our current environment I have to say its a life saver and I'm very pleased with it! The only thing I had an issue with was placing the treadmill where I wanted it. They had it on a truck that had a lift to lower it. It's super heavy so keep that in mind if there are any stairs involved. But once in place it folds up nicely with wheels if you ever did need to move it. Overall very happy with my purchase.

After turning our treadmill on for the first time, the incline immediately went to maximum and would not respond to input. We tried all the standard troubleshooting of power cycling, recalibrating the incline, etc all with no success. We then tried to contact NordicTrack support, and after trying everyday for a week with no response, we returned the defective item to Amazon for a refund.
The treadmill seemed solid, and if it worked I'm sure it would have been great. Just don't expect any support if you get a dud or have any issues.

We have been so pleased with everything about this treadmill! The quality is great for all of us - from petite women to large men. The instructions were very clear and my husband and son were able to build the treadmill without a problem. I will say that assembly is probably a two person job, since the machine is substantial and might be too heavy for one person. We are all really enjoying the iFit workouts - from the hikes in the Alps to walking tours of the Egyptian pyramids to runs around Paris. There is a workout for every level of fitness. I would highly recommend this treadmill to anyone who is wanting a great commercial quality treadmill for their home.

I will say this thing is really hefty, which is probably a good thing in terms of long lasting quality. The people that dropped it off werenât willing to put it anywhere except the foyer, so good luck if you need to move it down stairs like I did. Youâre gonna need help â but again not a bad thing in terms of build quality, it just makes for a harder assembly.
What I liked about the product is the quality, itâs not too terribly noisy, about on par with what youâd expect from a commercial gym treadmill, comes with cool work out programs built in, and it folds up pretty nicely if you need it to. Itâs also got Bluetooth so you can hook your devices up to it and play music or watch media through your phone or laptop.
What I didnât like is that there are absolutely no USB ports for charging or linking your phone to. I think it would be nice to have applications along with the interface, like YouTube, Spotify, or even just web browser functionality since this thing actually connects to the internet. Maybe they can update that with a software update or something.
Overall, nice package for its intended purpose which is working out...just a missed opportunity in regards to features that I would have liked to see.

Shocked that I was delivered a defective 2450 Commercial model. Could only find out it was faulty after 5 hours of assembly was done. Now I had it disassembled and reboxed, which took nearly 4 hours. Nordic Track costumer service told me on the phone on March 18 that they would do in-home assembly by their expert for a fee. But that was no longer an option a day later when I tried placing the order with them directly and they urged me to order via Amazon because it works arrive 1-2 weeks earlier in only 7-9 days. Nordic Track would not respond to my emails or calls for 5 days. I was on hold for 40 minutes and they told me to return the defective item to Amazon because of burnt smell could be a fire hazard and the Decline Motor noise was abnormally high at 3x the loudness that we heard inside gyms and the cushion lever for "soft" or firm did not work or change or move more than a 1/8th a turn and was supposed to turn much more and lock in for cushion softness change but it did not.

The controller stopped working making the machine unusable in less than 5 months with a usage of ~15 miles per week. Definitely didn't expect this to happen so fast with a commercial series. Reaching Nordictrack customer service rep was difficult (lots of hits and tries) but once reached, after few troubleshooting steps, she helped with a replacement order for the controller. But the sad part is that the time to deliver is not clear (it could take 4 to 6 weeks) therefore my training is messed up now. I have to revert to my four years old Weslo which is still working fine (after a motor belt replacement).
